dialogues.speaker: LOUISE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Memory is a strange thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A modern home built on the shore with a large deck. The skin of the lake is a cloudy mirror. LOUISE BANKS stares up at the sky, leaning against the de railing. Merlot glass in one hand. Louise has a clean, timeless look about her; the kind of woman who ages gracefully. Short hair.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: It doesn’t work like I thought it did. We are so bound by time; by its order. She steps back inside, a little tipsy, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacks of books on shelves and tables. A telescope agains glass wall. And dry-erase boards, marked with foreign languages. Different colors for different dialects.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Maybe there’s a higher order. Mingled here are also dinner plates. Candlelight.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Darling, is there any more wine? She pauses when a deck light winks on outside. Her eyes sparkle when she sees something: A question, written on the glass, lit from outdoors. “Do you want to make a baby?”

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I used to think this was the beginning of your story.  Blue Draft (05/06/2015) 2. Louise goes right to the glass, wanting to touch the ques with her finger to make sure it’s real. CLOSE ON HER FACE: From outside looking in, a curious circular shadow is thrown from the deck light. But her ey start to water. In the background, the bedroom door hangs open and the silhouette of a MAN leans against the frame, watching her Louise turns around, smiling again. We know her answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louise cradles a NEWBORN GIRL in her arms. Her name: HANN Hannah reaches up. Crooks her tiny hand around Louise's finger.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: A NURSE starts to take baby Hannah to give Louise some re Hannah BLEATS and reaches for her mother. Louise smiles through the exhaustion and pulls her back--

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Okay, come back, come back to me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four-year-old HANNAH dressed as a cowgirl. On a toy riding horse with wheels for hooves. Giggling like she can’t stop.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I remember moments in the middle. She pulls both finger-guns, aimed at us.

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: Stick ‘em up! INT. HANNAH'S ROOM — NIGHT 5 Eight-year-old Hannah is tucked in bed. Said to us as a prayer:

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: I love you.  Blue Draft (05/06/2015) 3. INT. LAKE HOUSE — NIGHT Twelve-year-old Hannah glowers at us:

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: I hate you! --and storms into her room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve-year-old daughter HANNAH lies, eyes closed. Hannah is pale. Her head has been shaved in the last mont

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And this was the end. Louise holds her daughter’s hand in hers. Her thumb traces Hannah’s knuckles. A life monitor beeps as Hannah’s heart stops. Hannah’s eyes roll up and she sighs her final breath. Louise’s grip on her daughter tightens. Trembling. A Nurse starts to pull Louise away, but she hangs on-- no it’s mother trying to return to her baby girl--

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Come back-- come back to me, baby-- Louise is unaware she’s crying. Hannah remains motionless

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But now I’m not so sure I believe in beginnings and endings. There are days that define your story beyond your life. CUT TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Like the day they arrived.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Storybook blue, patched with cumulous clouds. Drifting down to find a tree line in motion. Looking into a car on a road.  10 iL 12 Yellow (06/11/2015) 4.

dialogues.text: Louise parks her car end steps out. Her hair is longer he and there’s no wedding band on her finger. She carries herself like someone who’s learned how to be alone, handling her briefcase, coffee, keys, etc. It’s oddly quiet in the garage around her. EXT. UNIVERSITY CAMPUS — DAY 10 Louise crosses campus. Absorbed in her thoughts. Overhead, a pair of F-22 fighters slice across the sky. EXT. STUDENT CENTER - MOMENTS LATER 1i Louise passes the campus center. A crowd of STUDENTS are huddled around the glass outside student center, looking in at a large TV. The crowd is to dense for Louise to see what is on the TV. Louise frowns, but keeps going. Overhead, a second pair of fighter jets rocket past. Louise looks up at the sky. Apprehensive. INT. UNIVERSITY CLASSROOM — DAY 12 Louise enters a classroom, leaving the door open behind h Out in the hall, a couple of STUDENTS run by, but it’s unclear if they’re late for class or it’s something worse Louise steps to her desk to unload her briefcase and ther The course name is written on the blackboard behind the d “Advanced Linguistics” and “Dr. Louise Banks.”

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Good morning, everyone. No response. Louise finally looks to the class to discove Only FOUR STUDENTS seated in an otherwise empty classroom LOUISE (CONT’D) Where is everyone?  Pink (05/18/2015) 5. The Grad Students in the room shrug. These are the hardco learners, with their laptops out and textbooks open. The class session BELL chimes over the PA. Louise looks b at the door, silently considering something, then decides LOUISE (CONT’D) Well, let’s get started. Today we're talking about Portuguese, and why it sounds so different from the other Romance languages. Louise walks to a MAP of western Europe on a rolling ease parked next to a TV.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The story of Portuguese begins with the Kingdom of Galicia, in the middle ages, where the language was seen as an expression of art. The way it was written and spoken was rooted in aesthetics. One Grad Student’s phone CHIMES with an alert. Louise pau thinking what the other Students are thinking--

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Any news you want to share? The Student reading his phone frowns, suddenly nervous.

dialogues.speaker: GRAD STUDENT WITH SMARTPHONE
dialogues.text: Uhh, Doctor Banks? Can you turn on the TV to a news channel? Louise grabs her TV remote and turns the set to CNN, to reveal AERIAL FOOTAGE from a helicopter, also live, as a REPORTER narrates in a near panic:

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER IN HELI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Are you seeing this!? Oh dear god what is that noise-- WHAT IS IT-- should we be this close to it?! FOOTAGE shows wilderness, where a STRANGE, OBLONG OBJECT hovers over the tree line. It absorbs sunlight and its dimensions are difficult to grasp -- at times it appears almost concave, poised as if to dig into the planet’s cru Another helicopter edges into view, and suddenly the scal the object is clear: It’s the size of a massive skyscrape Bumper text at the bottom of the screen reads: “STRANGE CRAFT IN MONTANA”  Pink (05/18/2015) 6. Amid the WHUFF of the helicopter, a reporter on location shouting in a voice on verge of a nervous breakdown: The audio cuts out and an ANCHORWOMAN takes over. Cutting the studio where she pulls her attention to the camera:

dialogues.speaker: ANCHORWOMAN
dialogues.text: The object, uh, apparently touched down forty minutes ago just north of I-94, we're, we’re waiting to hear if this is perhaps an experimental vessel or-- She looks for help off-camera and they cut to: MORE FOOTAGE, closer to the ground. The oblong ship is immense. And seemingly without creases or windows.

dialogues.speaker: ANCHORWOMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hold on, it-- I’m learning that more objects like this have landed in as many as eight other locations around the world. We’re waiting for confirmation-- yes? Can we--? Okay-- New footage: a live feed in Japan. An identical CONCAVE S is parked above a stadium lot.

dialogues.speaker: ANCHORWOMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is from a site in Hokkaido! The Grad Students all stare in silent horror at the foota One of them stands up and gathers his stuff, ready to lea But he only gets as far as standing up. Unsure what to do next; where to run to.

dialogues.speaker: ANCHORMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (panicked) This is worldwide, it is happening right now! We don’t-- do we know where they came from? A campus SIREN spins up; the kind used for tornado warnin The STUDENTS now start to get their materials together, t leave. Louise snaps out of her shock, and with authority:

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Okay, yes, let’s go. Class over.  13 14 15 Pink (05/18/2015) 7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louise joins a FLOCK of people on campus hurrying to the parking structures. Nearly everyone keeps looking up from time to time. The SIREN is louder here. Above: Another pair of FIGHTER JETS fly overhead. EXT. UNIVERSITY PARKING STRUCTURE — DAY 14 Louise gets to her sedan, climbs inside, windows down. He satellite radio plays as she powers the car --

dialogues.speaker: PRESS SECRETARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But for now we’re simply asking for cooperation while authorities assess the object. Until further notice, the site is a no-fly zone. From the street: Sounds of a car accident. It startles he

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So you’re saying it’s not ours? Do you know if it’s even from Earth? Louise opens her door and steps out again, to look down a The wreck below. The aftermath. The two DRIVERS panicked on edge but uninjured.

dialogues.speaker: PRESS SECRETARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We're still collecting information, coordinating with other nations. We're not the only ones with one of these in our back yard. Louise returns to her car and straps herself in.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: If this is some sort of peaceful first contact, why send twelve? Why not just one? She backs out, tires yelping at her quick getaway. EXT. LAKE HOUSE — EVENING 15 Her sedan pulls up at the lake house from the opener.  16 7 18 Blue Draft (05/06/2015) 8. INT. LAKE HOUSE —- FRONT ENTRY - EVENING 16 Louise enters with her cell phone to her ear, carrying he valise.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: (into phone) I don’t know, Mom, I’m listening to the same news coverage. (beat) Don’t-- Mom, don’t bother with that channel, how many times do I have to tell you not to pay attention to those idiots? (beat) All right then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Traversing a hallway to bedrooms. Louise pulls her shoes by the heel, switching hands with the phone as she goes.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Do I sound worried? Exactly. Louise pauses at an open bedroom door halfway down the ha

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Me? Oh, you know. The same. There’s a tiredness in her answer. Like she’s been down t road with her mother before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An empty room, save for a couple of stray book boxes and neglected stationary bike in the corner. Louise surveys the room from the door.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: I’m fine, Mom. (not really) Okay, call me later. She disconnects the call and leans against the door frame Staring into the empty room with a quiet sadness. Finally, having come to some decision, she pushes off aga  19 Yellow (06/11/2015) 9. INT. LIVING ROOM — LATER 19 Louise, alone, on the couch. Half a bottle of wine left. The place is furnished nicely, but there are telltale sig of a single occupant in a larger space. No family photos. A recliner by the couch has become a surrogate bookshelf. TV is on. More coverage of the alien landing.

dialogues.speaker: CNN REPORTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: .+--and at around eight hours after landing, there are still no signs of what might be called ‘first contact.’ The objects measure at least fifteen hundred feet tall-- Changing channel. Footage changes to a snowy tundra where another UFO has landed and flattened a section of fence l This is a foreign channel. Louise gets international stations. The anchor speaks in Russian. New channel: Another SHIP, hovering over the ocean. AERIAL COVERAGE: Fleets from three different nations thre each other for possession of the massive UFO.

dialogues.speaker: NETWORK REPORTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --none of whom can claim because this ‘object’ as it’s being called is actually hovering over international waters. One Iranian cruiser has fired across the bow of the Indian fleet-- Louise changes the channel. Finding: The press room in the west wing of the White Hou

dialogues.speaker: PRESS SECRETARY
dialogues.text: We have to entertain the idea that, if it is a kind of vessel, it may be unmanned. Regardless, we have a protocol for scenarios like this-- The word “protocol” instantly sours Louise to the news. S mutes the TV and shuffles off to her bedroom--  20 21 22 23 24 Yellow (06/11/2015) 10. INT. LOUISE’S BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS 20 --picks up a remote off a nightstand and turns on a TV fa her bed. More news, the volume low. INT. LOUISE’S BEDROOM —- MORNING 21 Louise is asleep in bed. The covers are a mess. She’s spooning extra pillows as if they were a bedfellow. Louise wakes with a start, as if from a dream. EXT. UNIVERSITY CAMPUS — MORNING 22 Louise returns to work. The campus is empty. Two STUDENTS hurry between buildings Louise passes the student center. It’s too quiet. INT. UNIVERSITY CLASSROOM — MORNING 23 Louise enters her classroom. No one has showed up. INT. LOUISE’S OFFICE - DAY 24 A cramped office with a window looking out on the city. Sirens wail in the distance. Louise has barely decorated the place. It’s the sign of someone untethered from the world. Closed off. She sits a her desk, grading papers. Streaming video news coverage p on her computer.

dialogues.speaker: ANCHORWOMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Forty-eight hours later, and still no further developments from the sites of the twelve UFOs. Borders are closed and flights--

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Two days and already the public expects us to know the answers. Louise turns to see the source of the voice at her office door. COLONEL WEBER (50s) wears civilian clothing but his body language screams career military. Callused hands, sh eyes, rigid posture.  Yellow (06/11/2015) 10A. He steps in and reaches to her computer, powering off the speakers. Behind him, two large MEN stand guard in the ha

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Who are you?  Yellow (06/11/2015) il. Weber has his I.D. ready; shows it to her.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: I’m Colonel G.T. Weber. You and I never formally met but two years ago you did some Farsi translation for Army Intelligence.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: I remember. Alan Boudreau hired me.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Alan works for me. You made quick work of those insurgent videos. Louise crosses her arms. He’s touched a nerve.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: You made quick work of those insurgents.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: You have another two years on your SSBI so you still have top secret clearance. That's why I’m in your office, and not at Berkeley.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Okay...

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: I need you to translate something for me. As one of the men guarding the door shuts it, giving them total privacy, Colonel Weber places a pocket-sized digita recorder on Louise’s desk. He hits PLAY. White noise, shuffling. Then murmured talk, and: MAN’S VOICE (on recorder) Why are you here? In response: A SERIES OF SOUNDS that have no Earthly comparison. An audio mixture of organic clicks, rushing water, whispers, and low-octave moaning. MAN’S VOICE (CONT’D) (on recorder) Can you understand us?  12. Almost immediately, the SOUNDS return, this time slightly different. The bass tone is lower. The whispers raspy. Louise listens, rapt. As if she’s waking up from a long sleep. She leans in. Weber studies her face while she listens. MAN’S VOICE (CONT’D) (on recorder) Where did you come from? Before an answer is heard, Weber stops playback and takes back the recorder.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Well? What do you make of it?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Is that...

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Yes. The weight of his answer settles on Louise. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: How many?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: How many what?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: How many of them were speaking? Weber raises an eyebrow at her but answers.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Two. Assume they were not speaking at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Are you sure? Do they have mouths?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Keep your focus on the sounds. Weber replays a portion of the recording. The alien VOICE sounds even stranger a second time. COLONEL WEBER (CONT’D) What would be your approach to translating this? Does any of it sound like words to you? Phrases?  Pink (05/18/2015) 13.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: (said not as a question) What can you tell me.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: I can tell you it’s impossible to translate this from an audio file. To do this right, I need to be there. Interacting with them. Weber bristles at this.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: You didn’t need that for the Farsi translations.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: It was Burushaski, not Farsi, and I didn’t need it because I already knew the language. This-- (points at recorder) This is a whole new ball game.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: I know what you’re doing.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Tell me what I’m doing.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: I’m not taking you to Montana. It’s all I can do to keep it from becoming a tourist site for anyone with TS clearance.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: I’m just telling you what it will take to do this job.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: We will set up a safe room at a facility here in town where you can observe video of the conversations in real-time. I’1l put you on the line with our team at the site.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: No.  Blue Draft (05/06/2015) 14.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: (beat) What do you mean, ‘no’?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: It won't work that way.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: You’1l make it work. Her patience wears thin.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Have they spoken to us in English?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Have they played back any of our media, or given you any indication they understand us? Weber doesn’t have a reply for this. His eyes shift. LOUISE (CONT’D) So in order for this to work, I might have to teach them English. The basics. Nouns, verbs. I can’t do that remotely. I have to be in the room with them. Weber and Louise stare down.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: There is one opportunity here, and that is to study them remotely. If I leave here, your chance is gone. Weber turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Colonel... You mentioned Berkeley. You going to ask Danvers next? Weber pauses at the door.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Maybe, why?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Before you commit to him, ask him the Sanskrit word for “war” and its translation.  25 26 Pink (05/18/2015) 15. She grins at him. Weber exits. After he leaves, her grin fades. INT. LOUISE’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 25 Louise is asleep in her bed. Again with the formation of pillows around her. She wakes to a rhythmic thumping. Low; dull. Her hand goe her heart. It’s not her heart. From her bedroom window: A distant flying object vaguely a helicopter. One thing is clear: it’s on fast approach. As it gets closer, treetops bend and leaves scatter. INT. LOUISE’S LIVING ROOM - MOMENTS LATER 26 Dressed in a bathrobe, Louise crosses to the front window looking out on her wide, flat front yard. SPOTLIGHTS shine into her house, STROBES pop. We are so u to how a helicopter sounds, but this is different. The en noises, the rotors -- it’s more muscular; threatening. The lights finally dim to reveal: A Sikorsky UH-60 Blackh has touched down on the lawn. The passenger door is open, slid back to reveal someone riding in the rear compartmen Her doorbell rings. Louise answers it. Weber stands at the door, now in military uniform.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Colonel?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Gavisti.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: That's the word. But what did Danvers say it means in Sanskrit?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: He said it means an argument. What does it really mean?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: “BR desire for more cows.”  27

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Pack your bags. It hits Louise: She got the job. All right. Give me twenty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: You have ten. Louise glares at Weber for just a moment, then dashes off her bedroom. EXT. LAKE HOUSE —- PRE-DAWN 27 Louise (now dressed and carrying an overnight bag) hurrie for the Blackhawk. The rotor blades flatten the grass on lawn and pull at Louise’s coat. Weber helps Louise inside and then shuts the door. The helicopter rises immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louise drops into a bench seat still holding her bag. As she buckles in:

dialogues.speaker: IAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Language is the foundation of civilization. Across from her: IAN DONNELLY (late 30s), Oxford shirt, w hair, fierce eyes, and a smile in the corner of his mouth that makes it hard to tell what he’s thinking. Ian holds a book. He’s reading from it.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Pardon?

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: “It is the glue that holds a people together, and it is the first weapon drawn in a conflict.”

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Louise, this is Ian Donnelly. Neither Louise nor Ian offer to shake hands. They study o another as they talk.  Yellow (06/11/2015) 7.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: That’s quite a greeting.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: You wrote it.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: It’s the kind of thing you write as a preface. Dazzle them with basics.

dialogues.speaker: TAN
dialogues.text: It’s good. Even if it’s wrong.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Wrong?

dialogues.speaker: TAN
dialogues.text: The cornerstone of civilization isn’t language. It’s science.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Ian is a theoretical physicist from Los Alamos. He is the man with the questions. You will be reporting to me but you’1ll be working with him when you’re in the shell.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: The shell?

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: That’s what they’re calling the UFO.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Priority one: What do they want, where are they from? Weber speaks them as orders. Ian thinks it’s a conversati

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Yes, but beyond that: How did they get here? Are they capable of faster-than-light travel? Ian pulls a Moleskine notebook from his pocket, excited t share from it--

dialogues.speaker: IAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I've prepared a list of questions, starting with some “handshake” binary sequences--  28 29 30 Yellow (06/11/2015) 18.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: How about we just talk to them first? Before we start throwing math problems at them.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: This is why you’re both here. Ian nods as he puts his notebook up, but it’s clear he’s anxious to get past the small talk and on to the big idea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wide angle on approach. A mile out. Roads and highways ar crowded with traffic, up against military blockades. In the distance: The ALIEN SHIP, in silhouette behind the rising egg-yolk sun. The ship dwarfs the wilderness around it and stands out l a Massive, strange edifice that would seem ancient were i not hovering over the ground. At this distance, a low TONE starts to resonate in everyo sternum. The Blackhawk lances over the treeline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUISE'S POV: The alien ship towers over the field. It se impossibly balanced, as if it could tip over and crush everyone at any time. A mile away, a series of tents have been erected. Up clos the ship looks majestic; ominous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louise and Ian stare out the side window at the ship.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Every thirteen hours a sort of door opens up, at the base. That’s where we go in.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: How many of us are here?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: You're the only scientists going in. But you both have a team here--  31 Yellow (06/11/2015) 19.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: A team? What kind of team?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Mostly NSA. Cryptanalysts, a couple of signal processing experts... A phone handset’s cradle lights up by Weber. He answers i

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: (sotto, to Tan) When’s the next meeting? Ian shrugs -- he just got here. He’s busy making a SKETCH the ship in his notebook. His notebook is a tiny library all his thoughts and ideas. Weber hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: We’ll need to hurry you through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Weber, Ian, and Louise are escorted out of the helicopter and into base camp. The camp is divided into t clusters of tents/buildings: OPERATIONS and SCIENCE. CAPTAIN MARKS (barely 30, disciplined; a man of rules) me Weber and updates him as they walk:

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN MARKS
dialogues.text: Materials team called in with some early analysis.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN MARKS
dialogues.text: Normally you find three or four elements in base material. Humans have eleven. That thing is made of every single element known to us plus a dozen we’ve never seen. Weber frowns, worried. But Ian has the opposite reaction: face lights up in wonderment, and a hundred questions pil in his mind but then —-

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: All right. Take these two to Kettler.  32 33 Yellow (06/11/2015) 20.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN MARKS
dialogues.text: Yessir.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: (to Ian and Louise) You will follow this man to medical. The procedure should take just a few minutes. Louise and Ian keep up with the Captain’s brisk march. A Medevac helicopter powers up on a pad nearby. Someone i strapped to a gurney inside, flanked by two Paramedics. Ian notices. So does Louise. They exchange looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Marks leads them to a large tent. Louise looks back at the ship for a moment. Nervous. Behind her, Ian looks back at it too. Curious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A staff of military medical personnel are busy testing ne diagnostic equipment. Captain Marks opens a flap into a room where we find a ma scrubs with a tray of hypodermics. This is DR. KETTLER; professorial, even-toned voice, but a predator’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KETTLER
dialogues.text: Louise Banks and Ian Donnelly? Louise nods. Kettler gestures to two plastic chairs. They sit, while he prepares a syringe with a vial attached. DR. KETTLER (CONT’D) When is the last time either of you have eaten?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Last night.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KETTLER
dialogues.text: When is the last time you did something stressful?

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Does right now count?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Who was being carted off on the medevac?

dialogues.speaker: DR. KETTLER
dialogues.text: Not everyone is wired for what you’re about to do. Our brains aren’t always able to process experiences like this. (then) I’m going to get some blood from you, and give you an immunization dose that covers a battery of bacterial threats. Roll up your sleeves, please. Ian begins rolling up his Oxford shirt sleeve. Louise not Ian is complying, then follows suit. Kettler moves his tray over and wraps a band around Louis arm, just above her elbow. As he draws blood: DR. KETTLER (CONT’D) The booster is a kick to your system, so you might feel some side effects. Nausea. Dizziness. Headaches. A ringing in your ear like you have Tinnitus. Louise looks over at Ian to share a look of: Do you belie what Kettler just said? But Ian is staring out a window at the big ship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ian and Louise enter this tent that serves as the nerve center of base camp. The room is fitted with dozens of flatscreens, each one monitoring activity of a landing si in some other part of the world.

dialogues.speaker: AUSTRALIAN SCIENTIST, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Honestly they’ve been mostly quiet so far. And by the time we start to make any real progress, it’s over, and we're out the door again.  Yellow (06/11/2015) 21a, Weber is waiting for them, now in full uniform. Behind hi large white board. AUSTRALIAN SCIENTIST (0.S.) (CONT’D) We're trying to reduce our setup time, maybe limit the diagnostic gear so we can focus more on our friends across the glass.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How long are your sessions?  Pink (05/18/2015) 22. On the white board: Twelve columns, with labels of countr

dialogues.speaker: WALES / PAKISTAN / INDIAN OCEAN.
dialogues.text: Information is written under the columns, and spy satelli plus location photos are peppered throughout. It shows wh every country is doing at their separate sites. Standing at a MONITOR is a MAN in a suit and tie. Arms crossed over his chest. This is AGENT HALPERN: All busine His job is international relations. On the monitor is an AUSTRALIAN SCIENTIST talking via VTC

dialogues.speaker: AUSTRALIAN SCIENTIST
dialogues.text: The barometer readings don’t change, but like clockwork, after forty-six minutes and two seconds the gravity slowly shifts to slide us out of the room. Like we’re insects on a piece of paper and they’re easing us out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: Is there a scientific explanation for it? Like, is it for them?

dialogues.speaker: AUSTRALIAN SCIENTIST
dialogues.text: We think it’s for us. The air doesn’t seem to circulate in the chamber, so after about an hour we’d run out of oxygen.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: But it doesn’t take thirteen hours to pump fresh air into that room.

dialogues.speaker: IAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Atmosphere.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: If their atmosphere is different from Earth, it could take them hours to re-balance the oh-two content and pressure for us every time they open their door.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: So, you’re saying they could suffocate us if they wanted.  Pink (05/18/2015) 22a, Weber guides Ian away from Halpern and the monitors, back toward the way out of the tent.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Remember: We need answers as soon as possible. Why they are here. What they want, what they will give us. This is the priority.  35 36 Yellow (06/11/2015) 23.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Have they responded to anything? Numbers? Shapes? Fibonnacci?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: We can’t tell what they’re saying when they respond to “hello.” So don’t get ahead of yourselves. Louise frowns as a new question occurs to her.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: What have you figured out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the other side of basecamp: Communications. Weber pull back the flap and Louise enters, Ian trailing behind her. Inside: A dozen MEN AND WOMEN work at computer stations w large monitors and at an oversized white board. The monit all display the same kind of data: audio recordings, visu bouncing and fluctuating as the alien VOICES speak. Some of the members approach to shake Louise’s hand, and LIB their greetings before returning to analysis work. A few of them remain at their stations, headphones on.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: We're just getting started. Stepping back, Louise asks Weber:

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Why not send them in?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: (beat) Honestly, they all prefer to stay out here. Suddenly, a low, deep bass TONE vibrates the tent. A pen falls off a desk. A TECH grabs his coffee mug. The tent-t CLATTER against the support poles. It’s terrifying. COLONEL WEBER (CONT’D) That’s our ten-minute warning. INT. “CLEAN ROOM” — DAY 36 A miniature Silkwood. Contained showers. Dressing areas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Draft (05/06/2015) 24. Full HAZMAT suits hang on a wall. Captain Marks brings Ian and Louise in. They each have co swabs taped to their elbows now.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN MARKS
dialogues.text: Climb into these. I’ll help you with the helmet seals.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: What kind of radiation exposure are we walking into?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN MARKS
dialogues.text: Nominal. These are just for safety.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Is there physical contact with the, the-- am I the only one who has trouble saying “aliens”?

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN MARKS
dialogues.text: There’s a wall. Like a glass wall. You can’t get to them.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: What do they look like? A flashing light winks over the exit door. Captain Marks claps his hands: Let’s go. On Louise, wanting to get off this ride, but she follows- EXT. BASE CAMP — DAY A36 The Shell looms in the distance, at the other end of a mi long “road” formed in the grass from all the back-and-for A dusty PICKUP TRUCK waits for them, its tailgate down, a step ladder planted at its lip. A second TRUCK is already on the road, its bed loaded wit gear and two SCIENCE TECHS in similar moonsuits. Nearby, two DRONE OPERATORS launch a surveillance drone i the air, which then flies ahead of the trucks, toward the shell. Leading the way.  37 Blue Draft (05/06/2015) 25. Louise and Ian are led into their pickup truck. Bench sea has been set up, but it all feels a bit cobbled together. Weber (in his suit and mask) nods at a LIEUTENANT who loc the tailgate into place for them and slaps the truck: The good to go. The truck starts for the Shell. Louise stares at it with wide eyes. Soon, the sun eclipse the ship and the whole truck succumbs to shadow. HIGH ANGLE: From a perch above the Shell: the two tiny tr slow as they arrive underneath it. EXT. “THE SHELL” - MOMENTS LATER 37 The craft is even more intimidating close-up. Its surface the undercarriage portion seems to absorb light. It’s also floating twenty or so feet overhead. Louise and Ian join a small contingent of MILITARY PERSON also in HAZMAT suits, all attending crates of specialty g One of them gestures at: A SCISSOR LIFT parked directly under the Shell. Nearby, a second “backup” scissor lift sits parked. She follows Weber, Marks, and two other Science Techs (a total of 6). Her breath is loud in her helmet. She’s shak They step onto the Scissor Lift. Captain Marks pounds a button and they start to elevate. A safety CHAIN hooked to the guard rail on the lift RATTL incessantly. Louise notices it. Looks up again.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: It’s just hovering...

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: They probably traveled millions of light years, they couldn’t go an extra twenty feet? Said with a grin, but no one laughs. The lift is now so close overhead, they can reach up and touch it. The two TECHS do just that -- feeling the surfa for some purchase or change. But it’s so dark, there’s no real sense of dimension here.  38 Yellow (06/11/2015) 26. Ian tries, too. And suddenly they’re all reaching, feelin IAN’S GLOVED HAND curls into something. An edge. A hole t can’t be seen on the surface. It widens, as marked by his hand. Opening like a mouth to accept the lift inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking down from within the tunnel: Flashlights clack ON among the team, pointed up, seeking a sense of destinatio

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Is this how it always goes?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Yes. (beat) This is the easy part. Our job was recon. Now it’s your job. This does nothing to comfort Louise. Above: A distant, indiscernible light. Ian studies the surface of the tunnel as they ascend, mov his flashlight beam over it. In the light’s edge, it seem perfectly smooth, but in the full beam there’s a texture. The lift stops. One of the Techs cracks a GLOWSTICK and throws it straight up. Louise watches it arc up... then veer to one wall, bounce and then it settles AGAINST THE WALL. Without falling.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN MARKS
dialogues.text: Here’s where it starts to get strange.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: “Starts?” Everyone in the lift rises maybe an inch, like balloons. Several of them immediately grab hold of the railing. Louise looks down at her HAZ-MAT boots. Noticing the lowe gravity here. How easy it would be to float away. That’s just what TECH 1 and TECH 2 do -- they grab their gear, bend at the knees, and then launch upward in a floa slow-motion leap...  Yellow (06/11/2015) 26a. Ian lets out a spontaneous little LAUGH as he sees them g slowly righting themselves to the shift in gravity until they’re both standing next to the glowstick. Captain Marks follows, like it’s nothing; like it’s a com to a job. Ian looks to Louise, as if they're both at the top of a r in a theme park and he’s looking to see if she goes first She’s terrified. So he jumps.  39 Pink (05/18/2015) 27. Ian lands gently, maybe twenty feet up. He looks down at them, opens his mouth to say something, can’t figure out answer, so instead he turns to face the “top” of the tunn And he slowly walks after the Techs. The light-and-dark i the tunnel casts eerie reflections on his mask. All that’s left is Louise and Weber. He can hear her breathing shallow inside her suit.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: This. I don’t. I don’t know if.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: All right. It’s okay. He holds onto her. Firm. Calm. Wise. And then he launches them both. Louise looks up, wide-eyed, fearful she’s breaking the la of physics, but tucked in next to Weber... They “swim” toward the others, leaving the lift behind... And then they come to rest on the wall/floor of the tunne Louise finds her footing. And her breath. And they walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chamber has no hard corners or edges. Vaguely rectangular. The room is bisected by a semi-transparent wall. The wall be seen through, but it renders the other side milky and foggy-- it’s uncertain if the atmosphere on that side is sort of gas, or if the barrier just makes it seem so. The TECHS with Weber and Marks quickly set up an arsenal video, audio, and other recording equipment to face this glass-like partition. Chemical sniffers. IR and UV camera Barometers. And most disturbingly, an old-tech detection among the high-tech: A CANARY IN A CAGE. On the other side, the room seems empty. Louise and Ian are speechless. Their breathing is loud in their ears. Colonel Weber steps up to them.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: What happens now?  Yellow (06/11/2015) 28.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: They arrive.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: And you’ve always worn this gear?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: The suits? Yes.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: So they haven’t really seen what we look like.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: What are you getting at?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Context. Comparative data streams on the Techs’ small monitors. Th speak quietly into their headset mics behind the group:

dialogues.speaker: ENVIRONMENTAL TECH 1
dialogues.text: Barometric down two point one.

dialogues.speaker: ENVIRONMENTAL TECH 2
dialogues.text: No change in temperature. A sound from the other end of the room quiets everyone. They look to the wall, squinting into the haze... TWO ALTEN FIGURES enter the room, and cause a breathtakin silence. They move in a foggy silhouette, making it impossible to much detail. They appear quadropedal with several appenda along the torso that serve as arms. The arms are spread equally around their bodies like spokes of a wheel. One seems a bit shorter and stouter than the other. Otherwise, their forms in the blurry mist are the same. As they approach their podium, the forms undulate in ways that make them seem like deep-water fish. There is no hin cavitation around them, yet the aliens move in a way best described as “swimming.” The silhouettes settle behind the raised podium. Louise and Ian stare in awe of the creatures. Louise tens realizing she’s leading the session. Ian is the only one the group smiling and nodding to himself, coolly confiden This is right where he’s supposed to be.  Yellow (06/11/2015) 29,

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: You’re up, Doctor Banks. Louise tries to control her breathing. Shrouded in the mist beyond the glass, the aliens stare b

dialogues.speaker: ENVIRONMENTAL TECH 1
dialogues.text: (quietly) Oxygen level dipping, point three.

dialogues.speaker: ENVIRONMENTAL TECH 2
dialogues.text: (quietly) Gravity stable inside the chamber. Ian squints his eyes and leans in.

dialogues.speaker: TAN
dialogues.text: Seven? Seven arms? (to Louise) Are those arms? Louise steps forward. Hesitant. Close to the boundary.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Hello. Beat. No reaction. The vague alien forms stand and wait. are a good head taller than Louise. She clears her throat. Still on the verge of an overload shock and stress. LOUISE (CONT’D) Hello. The blurry shapes seem to undulate, but it’s unclear if t are moving or if there is some distortion in the partitio between their space and Louise’s. Louise gestures at them, looking for some possible gestur response: LOUISE (CONT’D) Hello. Can you hear me? (then) Can you hear-— She’s interrupted by a sudden LOW NOISE from the other si Followed by a strange endcap: Flutter-tone. Tan and Louise both jump at the sounds, startled.  Yellow (06/11/2015) 30. LOUISE (CONT’D) (to Weber) Is this what they do?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Sometimes. (beat) What does it mean? Louise looks to Ian, terrified at her own answer:

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. The alien forms wait. Two “arms” on one of them flex and relax again, seemingly random.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If we can just... establish a common form of communication, maybe speech isn’t the-- She gestures at them again. No reaction.

dialogues.speaker: ENVIRONMENTAL TECH 1
dialogues.text: (sotto) Thirty-two minutes remaining. TIGHT ON Louise, trying to figure her next move, with everyone waiting on her... Panic rising...

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Doctor Banks... 40 INT. “CLEAN ROOM” — DAY 40 Louise takes off her suit’s mask and gulps in air. Her ey are red from nervous tears. She looks physically drained. She pulls off a glove and notices tremors in her hand. Ian strides in and begins shedding his suit. She watches Hears him softly laughing to himself.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Tan... Ian faces her, his hair wild and his eyes wilder.

dialogues.speaker: TAN
dialogues.text: Can you believe it? It’s just...  4l 42 Pink (05/18/2015) 31. He shakes his head and laughs again, but Louise detects m in his voice now. Ian moves suddenly for the bathroom stall behind a divide Louise hears him vomit into the toilet. Colonel Weber steps in, pulling off his helmet. Oxygen escapes with a soft hiss. He and Louise make eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: So. Am I fired? Weber sits down opposite Louise.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: You did better than the last guy.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: That doesn’t make me feel better.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Well, you got until 1900 hours to figure something out.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: What happens then?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: You go back in. Weber stands up to peel out of his suit. STAYING ON Louise, looking like she just escaped a fire a was told to run back into it... EXT. MONTANA LANDING SITE - EVENING 4l The sun sinks behind the sphere, casting long shadows ove the encampment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agent Halpern stands at the communications array, talking the Australian Scientist on the monitor, at the NZ site:

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: We're up in fifteen. Got any new intel? Anything working?

dialogues.speaker: AUSTRALIAN SCIENTIST
dialogues.text: We’ve been playing back some of their sounds.  Pink (05/18/2015) 32.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: Where does that get you?

dialogues.speaker: AUSTRALIAN SCIENTIST
dialogues.text: They play back audio at us, from some unseen source.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: Audio of what?

dialogues.speaker: AUSTRALIAN SCIENTIST
dialogues.text: Just bits of us talking in the room. Random clips of dialog. (beat) So, really, we’ve got nothing. 43 EXT. “CLEAN ROOM"/YELLOW TUNNEL - EVENING 43 Colonel Weber stands with Ian by the door. Both men are b in the full HAZ-MAT suits. Waiting.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: How long has she been in there.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: (calling through door) Doctor Banks? ...Louise? 44 INT. “CLEAN ROOM” 44 Louise sits on the bench, still in her clothes. The HAZ-M suit hangs across from her. Her leg bounces nervously. She’s not ready to go back in. can hear Weber outside:

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Did you two get any bright ideas on how to talk to them this time?

dialogues.speaker: IAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m really not that good at talking to other humans. It’s all on Louise. She sits up and looks away from the d afraid to step out... And her attention lands on something. On the wall. A SMALL WHITEBOARD. Used for recording the HAZ-MAT suit cleaning schedule. Names and shifts in dry-erase markers.  45 46 Blue Draft (05/06/2015) 33. Louise sees it and is seized by an idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louise emerges in her HAZ-MAT suit, cradling the whiteboa and a dry-erase marker.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: What’s that for?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: A visual aid.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: I’m never going to be able to speak their words, if they are talking, but they might have some form of written language. Or a basis for visual communication.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Okay. (then) Where do you start? INT. INTERVIEW CHAMBER — EVENING 46 CLOSE ON the whiteboard. Louise has written the word “HUM in large block letters. She stands by the whiteboard, marker in her trembling han Ian is with her, along with the team of TECHS behind them THE VAGUE ALIEN FIGURES are back, on the other side. Quie Louise speaks, and points to the word as she does:

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Human. She points to herself. Then to others on her side of the room, including Weber. LOUISE (CONT’D) Human. She points at one of the aliens.  Yellow (06/11/2015) 34.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you? Beat. The aliens seem unresponsive, until... They both RETREAT from the screen, deeper into the mist o their side of the room. For a moment, all is quiet. Louise looks to Ian, Ian look the Colonel. CLOSE ON A NEEDLE-GAUGE: Dead, registering no frequencies And then it SPIKES to the other side -- Before anyone can speak, THE CANARY SQUAWKS in its cage. Its wings flutter frantically. INK GLOBULES float from the mist. Like oil in glycerine. Thousands of drops; horizontal black rain, but intelligen They all start to form something against the partition: A brilliant LOGOGRAM. An inkblot coffee-cup stain with mesmerizing fractal embellishments. The taller, slimmer alien steps forward and says somethin Click-flutter-tone. Louise smiles. Nearly laughs. Wants to cry. She just had her first real exchange with an alien. LOUISE (CONT’D) (sotto) Are you getting this? Ian has taken control of a static video camera and holds at an angle that better captures the detail on the barrie

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Absolutely. It’s all downloading back at basecamp. One of the aliens “speaks” again. Flutter-tone, flutter-t THE LOGOGRAM MORPHS into another form, replacing the prev one. This one more intricate.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Whoa whoa, too fast, fellas. She lifts her marker to make a note. For the first time, hand isn’t trembling.  47 Pink (05/18/2015) 35. INT. “CLEAN ROOM” - NIGHT 47 Louise drops the whiteboard by the door. She doesn’t get more than her helmet/mask off before Colo Weber steps in and confronts her.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: I said talk to them, not teach them how to read. Do you understand what this could mean?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: It means if I play my cards right, they’ll take some Shakespeare home with them.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Only now you’ve made it twice as hard, trying to learn how to speak and read. That takes longer.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Wrong. It’s faster. Louise starts marching past him. Weber keeps up with her.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: I’m not saying no, I’m asking why.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: It’s the only way this will work.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Hey. Everything you do in there I have to explain to a room full of men whose first and last question is, ‘How can this be used against us?’ So give me something. Louise gestures at the whiteboard.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Kangaroo.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: In 1770, Captain James Cook’s ship ran aground on the coast of Australia. He led a party into the country and met the aboriginal people. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: One of his sailors pointed to the animals that hopped around with their young in pouches, and asked what they were called. The aborigine replied “Kanguru.”

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: What’s your point?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: It wasn’t until later that they learned “Kanguru” means “I don’t understand.” (re: whiteboard) I need this to make sure we don’t misinterpret in there. Otherwise this will take ten times as long. Time wasted is the key phrase to convince Weber.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: All right. I can sell that for now. But submit your vocabulary before the next session. (beat) And remember what happened to the aborigines. A more advanced race nearly wiped them out. Weber walks off with Captain Marks. Ian steps up, watching them go. Grinning at Louise:

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Is that true? The kangaroo story?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: No. But it made my point. Louise starts walking out the clean room, leaving Ian to shake his head in admiration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The team of NSA cryptographers works diligently on one th That alien logogram. As if it were the codes from an Enig machine and the key to winning a war. Louise steps in, se the frenetic action, and backs out.  4g Pink (05/18/2015) 36A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the busy activity at the various flatscreen monit stations, Halpern stands at one monitor, talking to a man from the Wales Science Team at their landing site.

dialogues.speaker: BRITISH SCIENTIST
dialogues.text: Spent most of the time just trying to establish a proper greeting. We're analyzing the playback now, to see if there is a pattern. I’m doing a Zipf law analysis. But I’m worried they aren’t really talking, it’s just how they breathe.  50 51 52 53 54 Goldenrod (08/03/2015) 37.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: Like the time I got bronchitis. OK, let me know if you figure that out. INT. SCIENCE TENT - LOUISE’S DESK - LATER 50 Louise studies at her desk. CELLO MUSIC distracts Louise, and she looks up. On a screen, the Japanese site is performing ‘Canon in D’ with a cellist in their interview chamber. Louise reviews the logograms from the session printed on large photo paper. The one on top is labeled “EARTH.” She’s circled pieces of the logogram in red pen, making n like “curling ascender = proper noun?” With a straight edge, Louise divides the circular logogra into twelve slices, isolating the different graphical elements in the alien symbol. She labels them 1 to 12. Louise blinks and takes a breath. Rubs the bridge of her and works a kink in her neck. Then leans back in, momenta renewed with focus. A high-pitched RINGING creeps into her ears. She winces--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four-year-old HANNAH giggles as she runs from us-- INT. SCIENCE TENT - LOUISE’S DESK - BACK TO SCENE 52 Louise sits up at her desk as if yanked from the memory. She takes a breath, rubs her forehead, confused by that little moment. She stares at the logogram on her desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON A LAPTOP SCREEN: Aerial footage of the Shell appears. Back from a safe distance. The Shell looks, as always, intimidating. 38. 55  56 Yellow (06/11/2015) 39. But now with the footage is a SINISTER SCORE added by sho jock radio host RICHARD RILEY, who emphasizes words--

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD RILEY
dialogues.text: This is aliens we’re talking about. The most important time in our history as a people is right now, first contact with whoever is inside this thing, and who do we have running the show? The government. The same government that ruined our health care and bankrupted our military. An image of the cluster of tents around the Montana site appears, obviously shot with a long zoom lens. RICHARD RILEY (CONT’D) Look at these people! Most of them don’t even have guns. We could be facing a full-scale invasion and our president is ready to roll over and let them take our country-- REVEAL the LAPTOP is in: The military barracks. And PRIVATE LASKY listens intently it. Nodding. Glancing out the open flaps of the barracks toward the giant Shell in the distance. Three bunks over, a group of SCIENTISTS watch a news prog on a separate TV, following riots somewhere. Could be Pra could be Detroit. One SCIENTIST shakes his head in disgus Outside, Louise walks past the barracks, on her way to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louise enters the tent to find Ian and Weber already here with other team members. Tan has a sketchbook, he’s busy with an art pencil, liste and nodding to the British Scientist on his monitor.

dialogues.speaker: BRITISH SCIENTIST
dialogues.text: We think we were able to reproduce some prime-number sequences back at them, so that’s something.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Congrats. You’re a parrot.  Yellow (06/11/2015) 40.

dialogues.speaker: BRITISH SCIENTIST
dialogues.text: It’s more than that, you cheeky bastard. Don’t you see? They can’t seem to follow our algebra system, but complex behaviors? That clicks. Beyond Ian: Weber stands with Halpern, watching Middic Eastern news coverage of an armored division mobilizing.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: Problem is, that shell dropped at the border, so when Pakistan rolled out their army to secure the site from locals, India got all fussy, amassing two armored divisions at the border.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: We can’t get them to stand down?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: And tell them what exactly?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Louise, Ian, this is Agent David Halpern with the CIA. Weber guides Louise and Tan away from the bank of monitor It’s clear he doesn’t like dealing with Halpern.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We need to gain ground today. You have your vocabulary list for me?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: (examines her list) You're going to teach them your name? And Ian’s?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: It’s so I can learn their names. If they have names. And so I can introduce pronouns later.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: These are all grade-school words. Eat. Walk. Tool. We need to get more specific.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Do you know what a Pulaski is?  Yellow (06/11/2015) 41.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: (beat) No.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: It's a tool. Used by firefighters. We can’t start specific. Weber makes a noncommittal noise and reviews the words. Ian reveals to Louise his sketch of an ALIEN.

dialogues.speaker: TAN
dialogues.text: Heptapod. Seven limbs. (gesturing at Louise) She’s right-- it’s useless until we can demonstrate some basics first.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: We have one question: What is their purpose here on Earth? It isn’t complicated. (softening) Help me understand. Louise goes to a larger whiteboard stationed nearby and writes the question “What is your purpose on Earth?”

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Okay, so this is where we want to get. Right? This question. (off Weber’s nod) To get there, we have to make sure they understand what a question is, and the nature of a request for information along with the response. Then there is clarifying the difference between a specific “you” from a collective “you.” We don’t want to know why Joe Alien is here, we want to know why all of them landed.  57 58 Blue Draft (05/06/2015) 42. She writes frantically over the words in columns, marking relations with arrows. As she speaks, her voice gets loud and more confident. This is her area of expertise. LOUISE (CONT’D) Purpose requires an understanding of intent. Which means we have to find out if they make conscious choices or if their motivation is so instinctive they don’t understand a “why” question, and biggest of all, we need to have enough of a vocabulary with them so we understand their answer. Colonel Weber nods and surrenders to her. Behind Weber, I grins devilishly at Louise, even winks at her.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: All right, all right, I get it. Stick to your list. Just-- Then: That low, bone-trembling BASS TONE echoing out from Shell, rattling the equipment. Weber scraps what he was going to say, opting instead for COLONEL WEBER (CONT’D) Good luck. INT. “CLEAN ROOM” — MORNING 57 Louise and Ian suit up again. Louise notices the tremors her hands have returned. INT. INTERVIEW CHAMBER — MORNING 58 Louise faces the semi-transparent wall, holding a dry-era marker in one hand. Ian stands near the whiteboard. Every is in full HAZMAT suits again. Weber isn’t here this time The heptapods watch Louise with a strange curiosity. Louise points at herself.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Louise. The whiteboard displays her name in large letters. Beat. One heptapod speaks. Whisper-—flutter-click.  Blue Draft (05/06/2015) 43. Inky drops float to the glass and a beautiful LOGOGRAM fo

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Well, that’s progress.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: No. That’s the symbol for “human” again. But with a little curl at the end of that leg. Probably to indicate a question.

dialogues.speaker: TAN
dialogues.text: They’re getting confused.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: You know what-- I can’t do it like this. I just-- Louise looks over at something behind the Environmental Techs: THE CANARY. The little bird flaps its wings and crooks its head at he It’s alive and well. Louise makes a decision. She takes her HAZMAT mask off.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Whoa whoa hey-- Weber's voice pipes in via intercom, from the ops tent:

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You’re risking contamination.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: They need to see me. Louise shirks out of the rest of her suit. She’s wearing civilian clothes underneath. She takes a breath. It doesn’t kill her. Louise moves a s toward the glass barrier... The heptapods advance closer to the barrier. Curious. For first time, we can see a bit more detail; more focus. Their skin is more mottled than a uniform color. Their to move slightly, not from breath but as a jellyfish. And th tips of one heptapod’s “feet” are dark with ink. Everyone holds their breath a beat. Slowly, Louise puts a hand on her heart and repeats:  Green (07/09/2015) 44. LOUISE (CONT’D) My name is Louise. She takes the whiteboard and writes furiously. Flips it around and shows: She’s drawn their symbol for “human” next to the English word “HUMAN” and then a great than symbol leading to her name. The two heptapods are unresponsive.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ian, introduce yourself. Ian noisily shirks off his HAZMAT suit. Louise looks on. Weber gets more uneasy by the minute.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Made me look like a beekeeper. Ian erases Louise’s name on the board and writes his.

dialogues.speaker: TAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My name is Tan. A magical thing happens next: The shorter, rounder heptap steps forward. Click-tone. A small logogram appears on th boundary in front of him. Then the taller one ambles close. Flutter-swallow. A different symbol appears in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: They have names.

dialogues.speaker: TAN
dialogues.text: Yeah... So what do we call them? Because if I try to make sounds like them, I will end up insulting their mothers.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Slim and Stout?

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: I was thinking Abbott and Costello.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: (grins) I like it. Cautious, yet mystified, Louise takes another bold action She steps for the boundary. The light from that mist on t other side of the glass illuminates her face, showing her wonderment.  Green (07/09/2015) 45. LOUISE (CONT’D) (quieter) You have names... You're individuals. Aren’t you. Tan and Captain Marks watch. Marks doesn’t like it.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN MARKS
dialogues.text: Doctor Banks... Louise then puts her HAND on the barrier. Leaves it there The shorter one (ABBOTT), drifts close, too. And through the vague cloud, something specific: It raise limb and puts a SEVEN-FINGERED ‘HAND’ on its side. Near Louise’s hand. She smiles, still partly terrified but also reassured.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Now that’s a proper introduction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Weber, Agent Halpern, and Doctor Kettler step to of Kettler’s work tables in a private conference, as if t just arrived in a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Tell me. Are they a contamination risk without the suits?

dialogues.speaker: DR. KETTLER
dialogues.text: No radiation. Nothing else we can detect, either. But I’d give them a strong cocktail, regardless.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Any other sites working like this?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: No. But no one else has made this kind of progress. You saw it. Weber doesn’t like this decision, but he concedes:

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: All right, no suits for those two. But watch them closely for any signs.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KETTLER
dialogues.text: (as they leave) Signs of what?

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: INT. INTERVIEW CHAMBER ~— DAY Louise shows the word “WALK” and Ian demonstrates. them wear their HAZMAT suits now.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Session three. We're into verbs. Slow and steady wins this race.

dialogues.speaker: A58
dialogues.text: Neither of

dialogues.speaker: BS8
dialogues.text: Costello saunters along his side of the wall and a heptap logogram appears. It’s simple yet complex, like a fractal line art. INT. INTERVIEW CHAMBER — NIGHT c58 Ian draws a Feynman diagram, next to a set of SCIENCE CAR

dialogues.speaker: IAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Session six. Had some trouble with basics, but they understand complex interactions right away. Not that it’s a race, but I’m totally ahead now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louise debates some element of a logogram with members of cryptography team in their tent, pointing at a magnified piece of one circular symbol.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Session eight was a failure. But it’s clear their logograms are made of twelve compartments. INT. INTERVIEW CHAMBER — DAY E58 Louise works with a spectrograph as Ian charts a basic geometric curve. The heptapods are unresponsive in their misty chamber.

dialogues.speaker: IAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Session eleven. How can they stare at me when I use simple math? INT. INTERVIEW CHAMBER ~—- MOMENTS LATER F58 A graphic on the glass animates, showing our solar system highlighting “EARTH.” INT. LOUISE'S OFFICE TENT — NIGHT G58 Louise practices drawing her own logograms, trying to mim the inkblot style. Nearby, the whiteboard with the goal: “WHAT IS YOUR PURPOSE ON EARTH?” Several words leading to question have been marked -- she’s taught them those.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Session fifteen. Back on track. She smirks at a frustrated Ian. Their attention is drawn

dialogues.speaker: THE BANK OF MONITORS
dialogues.text: Footage on screens of anxious crowds massing around other sites. Protesters, fanatics, the hopeful and the hopeless Ian and Louise watching the footage, disturbed by the eff on the public of the ships’ mere presence. EXT. BASE CAMP — MORNING J58 High angle above the camp at sunrise.  Blue Draft (05/06/2015) 47. 59 INT. “CLEAN ROOM”’/YELLOW TUNNEL - MORNING 59 Weber gives Louise a notecard before they step out.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: When Ian is done with his math portion, include this word on today’s vocabulary. Louise frowns and hands it back.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: No way. Ian leans over, takes the card and nods at Weber--

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, we can manage that. Louise, now unsure whom she needs to convince first--

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: It’s dangerous. We could come across as hostile.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Yes. But I trust you to choose your demonstrations carefully. 60 EXT. “CLEAN ROOM” /YELLOW TUNNEL ~ DAY 60 Ian and Louise approach the pickup truck. Louise takes th moment to speak quietly at Ian, through her teeth:

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: What the hell was that?

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: I know you’re the language expert, but I know how to talk to these guys. You don’t say ‘no’ to them. You say ‘yes’ and then find a way to control the situation.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: So you have them all figured out? Ian smiles sweetly at her. He’s not fighting with her.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: It wasn’t that hard.  61 Blue Draft (05/06/2015) 48. INT. INTERVIEW CHAMBER -— DAY 61 Captain Marks remains in the room in full HAZMAT suit, monitoring the equipment with another TECH. Ian looks on at Louise, worried. Louise holds a HUNTING K in her hands, the notecard tucked in one palm. On the semi-transparent wall facing her, the heptapods ha written a terse, angular symbol next to the word Louise h written: “WEAPON.”

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: There’s your word, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (through speakers) Let’s ask the big question now.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Hold on. We need to distinguish a weapon from other devices or else they’1l think everything is a weapon. Costello whisper-clicks at Abbott, then turns to leave. A doorway irises open on the far wall. Abbott wipes the podium and the logogram vanishes. The tw aliens begin to glide away from their stations-- Louise realizes they are leaving and calls out--

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wait. Wait! She steps to the boundary and puts her hand on it.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why are you here? Abbott crooks his head. Louise, desperate, looks back at the printer attached to still camera capturing everything written by the heptapod She riffles through the pages, looking for the words.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: What can I do? Louise gives him two print-outs.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Hold these up.  62 Yellow (06/11/2015) 49. Abbott looks back at the door where Costello left. Then a Louise and Ian. Louise finishes drawing. Shows the board to Abbott. Puts against the boundary. She’s attempted freehand drawing th gorgeous logograms, and she’s actually done a great job. It’s not quite the phrasing; she hasn’t taught them “why” instead uses “heptapods purpose Earth” with a curl on the logogram for Earth. Abbott stares a beat. And writes on the podium. As the logogram glows on the divider, Louise steps back i shock. She’s translated it already.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: What does it say?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: “Offer weapon.” The phrase sends a tense hush through the team. The unidentifiable light source in the interview chamber and the transparent wall clouds until it’s fully opaque. Louise, Ian, Captain Marks, and the other in-room Techs f each other as if they've just learned a terrible secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An eruption of sound and chaos, joining in mid-debate wit several people talking at once. Halpern is among them.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN MARKS LOUISE
dialogues.text: But you saw what they wrote-- ~-using a word they don’t fully understand!

dialogues.speaker: IAN AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: It could just be a request-- --or a warning-- Over the din of everyone talking and no one truly listeni comes the booming voice of Weber in his best stern father

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Enough. (as room quiets down) I can’t agree with any of you when you’re all talking at once. Now: I want to hear theories. Louise?  Pink (05/18/2015) 50.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: We don’t know if they understand the difference between a weapon and a tool. Our language, like our culture, is messy. In many cases one thing can be both.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: In addition, it’s possible they are wanting us to offer them something, not the other way around. Like the first part of a trade.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: How do we clarify their intention beyond those two words?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: I go back in there. In thirteen hours, we go in and clear this up.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: It’s more complicated than that.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: How is that complicated?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: Set aside our own reaction to the message, we have to consider the other nations and how they will interpret this. (pointing at monitor) Like China. Have you met General Shang? How about a little round of “meet the scary-powerful men.” Halpern points at a profile photo of a distinguished Chin man in dress uniform: GENERAL SHANG. AGENT HALPERN (CONT’D) The call-sign for him is Big Domino. Because he’s a tastemaker. Whatever Shang does, at least four other nations will follow.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: We're on good terms with Shang.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: But we can’t say the same for other nations where these ships have landed. And Russia has control of two sites. Twice the data.  Yellow (06/11/2015) 51.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: How is that relevant to this? A LIEUTENANT enters to address Weber:

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: Colonel, the Secretary of Defense is on the line for you. Weber reluctantly steps out. Halpern takes over:

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: We need to sit on this information until we know what it means. So we aren’t sharing with our enemies. We have to consider the idea that our ‘visitors’ are prodding us to fight among ourselves until only one faction prevails.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: There’s no evidence of that.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: Sure there is. Just grab a history book. The British with India. The Germans with Rwanda. They even got a name for it in Hungary. Halpern’s cell phone rings, and before he takes the call- AGENT HALPERN (CONT’D) We are a world with no single leader. It’s impossible to deal with just one of us. And with the word “weapon” now... Louise pales. Feeling like she just broke something. She looks for someone to talk to and finds Ian deep in though keeping his eyes on the twelve monitors.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: That was my doing. I taught them that. So, if we just go back in tonight, go in and, and-- Frenzied activity at the monitoring station draws their attention in time to see: AN EXPLOSION at one landing site, the plume of the firecl lighting up the urban-located Shell-~-  Pink (05/18/2015) 52. Communications Team Members stand up now, talking into th headsets in four different languages-—- ON THE CHINESE VIDEO STREAM, a Scientist is forcibly pull away by a Chinese Intelligence Officer who yanks at a cab and then the video feed BLACKS OUT. A moment later, a panicked Russian Officer does the same their feed. Two more black screens. Siberia and Black Sea Weber gets off the phone, focused on the feeds.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: What's going on? What was that explosion at Site Four? Halpern keeps his ear to his phone, but answers:

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: China and Russia are off the grid. They aren't speaking to anyone. Whatever they learned in their last session has them spooked-- (into phone) Yes sir. (to Weber) We have orders to do the same.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE AGENT HALPERN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What? These people are our Until we figure out what the allies! Ian, tell him. message means--

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: That is a bad idea. It sends a clear signal of hostility. If we start this—~ A fourth monitor goes dark: Indian Ocean.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: It’s already started. Halpern leans in at one station and orders a Team Member:

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: Put us on radio silence. ON ONE SCREEN: It’s their own tent, the camera pointed at Louise and Ian. Louise rushes to the mic--

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Listen, we got a message from the heptapods, “offer weapon--”  63 Pink (05/18/2015) 53. But as she says “offer” the U.S. SCREEN BLACKS OUT, leavi the other countries hanging.

dialogues.speaker: AUSTRALIAN SCIENTIST
dialogues.text: What is happening? U.S. Team, please respond. Louise whirls on Halpern--

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Dammit, Halpern! We should be talking to each other.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: You want to talk to them, find out what this means. Please. I will sleep better if you do. He holds up the printout with the words “OFFER WEAPON.” Louise grabs the page from him and storms off to her desk Ian (quietly boiling) passes by Halpern and hisses:

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: By then it will be too late. ON THE MONITORS: four of the twelve now blacked out, with rest talking over each other, panicked... And then a FIFT monitor goes dark. INT. SCIENCE TENT - LOUISE’S DESK -— NIGHT 63 Louise wears a set of noise-cancelling headphones at her desk, listening to the spoken heptapod language and tryin shut out the world beyond. She stares at one of the logograms as she listens to the audio. It’s a circular piece full of whorls and curls. Writing notes to herself as she does: “They have landed? Earth? Planet?” Louise underlines that last word, she hears a new voice:

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (pre-lap) What’s this word? Louise hears Hannah’s voice and closes her eyes-—  Yellow (06/11/2015) 54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louise and Hannah (age 8) sit on the picnic blanket, unde the shade of a stately oak tree. They share a story book. Hannah points at a page.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: “Planet.” Like Earth is a planet.

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: Mmmm-- what's that word?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: How many words are you trying to learn today?

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: All of them. Louise smiles and kisses Hannah on the forehead. HANNAH (CONT’D) Want to see my project for Mrs. Garriott’s class?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: All right little-nose, whatcha got? Hannah digs into her backpack and pulls out a sketch.

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: Supposed to draw what my Saturday morning cartoon would look like if I had one.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: What is this place? THE DRAWING depicts a Man and Woman (stick-figures) holdi up a really fat bird-like shape.

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: That’s supposed to be a book.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Who are these two people?

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: You and Daddy. The show is called “Mommy and Daddy Save the World.” Louise's smile sinks. She looks pained.  Blue Draft (05/06/2015) 55.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Well. That sounds lovely. (beat) You know, it’s okay to be upset that your daddy and I... Little Hannah breathes through her nose.

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: I know. I’m not. Louise brushes Hannah’s hair out of her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: We both love you, very much.

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: I know. (then) It’s just a cartoon. It’s not real. That same high-pitched WHINE escalates and-- 65 INT. SCIENCE TENT - LOUISE’S DESK - BACK TO SCENE 65 Louise flings off her headphones and tries to get up, but she’s dizzy. Ian gets up from his station to help her--

dialogues.speaker: IAN
