dialogues.text: Louise? You okay? Louise recovers from a sudden vertigo. She focuses on Ian

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: I... Yeah, fine. She bends over and takes a moment to refocus. When she st upright she faces a suspicious Weber, who’s come over.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: When was your last check-up with Kettler? Louise lets out a breath and passes him by, for the exit. Ian considers going with her. Weber gestures: Stay back. COLONEL WEBER (CONT’D) How about you?

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Me? I’m fine.  Blue Draft (05/06/2015) 56. Weber brings Ian close to Louise’s desk and surveys the heptapod writing scattered over it. He takes a moment and chooses his words carefully.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: A lot of work for one person.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: She’s not alone. We’re making good progress. We’re teaching each other physics and language.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Good. Learn as much as you can. In case we need to bench Doctor Banks.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: No-- you can’t do that. (recovers ) I’m saying, it won’t come to that.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: But if it does... Weber leaves Ian to consider this scenario.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KETTLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (pre-lap) How do you feel? 66 INT. MEDICAL TENT - DR. KETTLER’S OFFICE - MOMENTS LAT A pen light shines in Louise’s left eye.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Overworked. Kettler tries to be casual but comes off awkward:

dialogues.speaker: DR. KETTLER
dialogues.text: That makes two of us. I hear you collapsed in the ops tent.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Probably just lack of sleep. Kettler readies a syringe.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KETTLER
dialogues.text: Well, you're not getting radiation poisoning. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: DR. KETTLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We’ll see how your blood tests look, but for now I’m going to give you another boost. Try and sleep this one off, okay? He sinks the needle into her arm. Louise tries not to fli

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Armed SOLDIERS are stationed at regular intervals around tight perimeter. Disturbing, as the base camp previously not seem military-led. Their presence is slowly increasin Private Lasky stands guard, and looks back at the mammoth Shell above him. He’s joined by Private COMBS, who gives ship a similar look of aggression. They notice each other glaring at the ship, and share a wordless nod of solidari Two soldiers who both spotted the enemy. EXT. HILLSIDE NEAR BASE CAMP — DUSK 68 Ian sits atop a sleeping bag, staring out at the massive with a look just the opposite of Lasky’s glare. He has a sketchbook open, filled with mechanical drawings advanced equations, and notes to himself. Louise ascends the hill toward him.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Weber is looking for you. Ian smiles at her.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Why do you think I’m hiding out here? Come, join me. She considers it a moment, then sits down next to him as makes room for her on his sleeping bag.

dialogues.speaker: B68
dialogues.text: Goldenrod (08/03/2015) 58. Louise looks down at the camp, her concern all wrapped up the military population, while Ian keeps staring out at t massive shell a quarter-mile away. IAN (CONT’D) How are you so good at talking to something so unlike us? Louise notices the focus of his gaze and shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: There’s precedent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louise with Hannah at a RANCH with a horse. The horse's nostrils flaring, standing eighteen hands tall, a giganti creature to the scared little 8-year-old Hannah. But Louise puts her hands on the horse. Speaks to it.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Shh, shh. It’s okay-- The horse’s ears spin like radar dishes-- EXT. HILLSIDE NEAR BASE CAMP — BACK TO SCENE B68 Back with Ian and Louise on the hill.  Goldenrod (08/03/2015) 59.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: You know, you approach language like a mathematician.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: I‘ll take that as a compliment.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: You should! You steer us around communication traps I didn’t know existed. Which probably explains why I’m single. Louise studies Ian’s face to see if he’s being sarcastic. He’s not. This is honesty.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: My father worked for a big energy company. They’d relocate him every year to some new country, and I went with him. He used to say learning all those foreign tongues would make me the center of every party. But you know what people say when you're sixteen and fluent in seven languages? “You're smart.”

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Oh no. “Smart” is bad.

dialogues.speaker: TOUISE
dialogues.text: People are so afraid of smart. Ian stares at the sky.

dialogues.speaker: TAN
dialogues.text: When I was six, my parents bought me a globe. One of those big ones on an iron floor stand. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: IAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This was the same year I dressed up as a wilderness explorer for Halloween. My room was papered with hand-drawn maps of my neighborhood. (beat) I studied every inch of that globe, and it was the saddest moment of my childhood. Everything had already been explored. (beat) Next Halloween, I was an astronaut.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: “To boldly go...”

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: I’ve spent the last thirty years staring at the sky. Trying to find a way out there. Now it’s here, and I don’t know how I feel about it.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Because you might finally get to explore the galaxy?

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Because they’ve already explored it. Louise shivers; it’s getting cold up here. Ian drapes a blanket over her shoulders and shares it wit her. The two huddle close together, under the massive spherical Shell lit by drifting spotlights.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: I feel like everything here comes down to the two of us.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: That’s a good thing. Have you seen the jokers around us?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Promise me. We’ll do this together? Ian's smile falters, as he recalls his talk with Weber.

dialogues.speaker: TAN
dialogues.text: Yeah.  69 71 Yellow (06/11/2015) 61. EXT. BASE CAMP -— NIGHT 69 Aerial view. The compound has doubled in size. INT. “CLEAN ROOM” — NIGHT 70 Tan and Louise prep for another session. Ian vigorously applies antibacterial soap to his hands and arms, like a surgeon prepping for the O.R. Louise still refuses to don HAZMAT suit, but she ties her hair back in a ponytail. Captain Marks enters, carrying a pair of respirators with small oxygen tanks attached.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN MARKS
dialogues.text: New policy. Carry these on you when you're in the Shell.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: You're worried we'll run out of air inside? Why?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN MARKS
dialogues.text: Before the blackout, the Swedish site reported their last session ran long by about twenty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: But they were fine at the end of it, weren't they?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN MARKS
dialogues.text: They still wear full HAZMAT suits, doctor. Like the rest of the world. Tan and Louise trade looks. Dr. Kettler enters, with his medical bag.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KETTLER
dialogues.text: Let’s roll up those sleeves...

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 71
dialogues.text: 72 Yellow (06/11/2015) 62. INT. INTERVIEW CHAMBER — NIGHT 72 Louise leads the team. On the other side of the barrier, Abbott and Costello are waiting. Costello stands at the podium. Abbott is closer the glass barrier. The glass-like surface is still milky, no one can get a good look at them.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: (to Ian) They’re already here. Captain Marks stands at the back. Watchful.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN MARKS
dialogues.text: Show them the question. Louise takes a breath and holds up her whiteboard while t Techs set up the video equipment behind her. It reads, in subtitled logogram: “OFFER WEAPON?” Abbott and Costello make little movement. No answer.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: This isn’t working. Louise speaks directly to Abbott, stepping a bit closer:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you offering us something? She holds up the whiteboard again. Another quiet conference between Abbott and Costello. More ink floats to the barrier to form a complex LOGOGRAM followed by the translation in subtitles. “MUST LEARN MORE FROM IAN LOUISE”

dialogues.speaker: TAN
dialogues.text: They don’t have enough of our language to share it yet.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Let’s fix that. Captain Marks checks the flatscreen monitors and tablet interfaces behind them -- one for Louise, one for Ian.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN MARKS
dialogues.text: You're good to go. On one monitor, the library of new learned logograms is currently blank. Like a spreadsheet waiting to be filled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sentence on Louise’s flatscreen reads: “Ian gives Lou an apple because tomorrow she will be hungry.” On the monitor behind her: the library is FULL of logogra Abbott replies. The written logogram is displayed: A gorg interwoven circle of loops, whorls, and splotches.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: I think it’s what we wrote. (pointing) Look. This is the word for “apple” but it’s conjoined with their names... I can’t tell where it starts or ends.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: No front or back. Like their bodies. And the ship.  Blue Draft (05/06/2015) 64.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: How do you begin to craft a complex statement like this? The relation each symbol has to another... (then) You know what? We’ve never seen them write. Only the result. Let’s see them in the act of writing. Louise returns to the tablet. Erases the sentence on her screen. And then, instead of preparing words and displayi the result, she triggers the “live sketching” option that shows her writing the letters and words in real-time. She writes the sentence: “Louise writes so heptapods can her writing.” Abbott and Costello crook their heads. Then Abbott approaches the transparent boundary, which becomes clearer than ever before. Captain Marks notices. Tenses.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN MARKS
dialogues.text: (into mic) One is approaching the boundary with two, uh, limbs raised. Abbott reaches the boundary, holding up two of his seven “hands.” He places them at two points on the transparent and begins to draw. Ink issues from his hands as he does. Abbott writes a heptapod sentence in real-time. With two hands simultaneously. It is poetry in motion. A dance of ink. He begins at oppo ends, and then writes phrases and symbols in a perfect pa of arcs so that they connect as a circle at the end.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Oh my god. Nonlinear orthography. Ian catches up to what she’s saying.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: They’d have to actually think nonlinearly, then. Louise grabs a tablet synced to the large flatscreen and draws in heptapod logograms. She does it one-handed, but she’s quite good at it.  65.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (via intercom) Explain. As she draws her logogram, she walks him through it:

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Imagine trying to write a long sentence with two hands, starting at either end. To do that, you'd have to know every single word you’re going to write, and the space all of it occupies. Ian struggles to find reference to her logogram.

dialogues.speaker: TAN
dialogues.text: What is-- what are you writing? She completes the ornate symbol.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: I asked about predictability. If “before” and “after” mean anything to them. Or if they don’t know what that means. Ian shuffles through notes on his tablet.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: When did we teach them any of this? Abbott answers in heptapod with another elegant logogram. Louise smiles and nods at Abbott.

dialogues.speaker: IAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (astonished) You can read that?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (over intercom) Get back to the weapon. Louise sighs and uses her keyboard to type as she asks al

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Give weapon now? Abbott draws a simple logogram. The translation: “SOLVE” LOUISE (CONT’D) Solve what?  Blue Draft (05/06/2015) 66. The transparent boundary clears itself of all its writing Abbott then draws two lines that meet in the middle to fo one long, contiguous line. Abbott gestures at the timeline and speaks: Click-click. LOUISE (CONT’D) That’s their spoken word for time.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: I remember how it sounds. Then, Abbott draws a logogram on the far end of the line. Louise translates: LOUISE (CONT’D) Humanity. That’s us.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: So I see.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: At the end of our timeline. The logogram from earlier forms again: “SOLVE.”

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch. He’s giving us homework.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louise and Ian leave the trucks for the science tent, escorted by men on either side. Weber walks with them. Lo looks pale and slightly ill.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: What is the answer?

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: I don’t know yet. I have to dig into it, figure out what they’re even asking.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: This is your new priority. No more language lessons until you crack it.

dialogues.speaker: B74
dialogues.text: c74 75 76 Yellow (06/11/2015) 67. His voice fades as the group marches on toward the tents, unaware that Louise has stopped walking. She puts her hands on her thighs, suddenly nauseated. Nearby is a PUDDLE of rainwater. The moon is visible in reflection, as is the silhouette of the Shell. Louise stares at the puddle as a ringing swells in her ea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moonlit lake on the other side of a bedroom window. INT. LAKE HOUSE - DAY (FLASHBACK) c74 Four-year-old Hannah's feet curl, inside pajama footies. EXT. BASE CAMP —- BACK TO SCENE 75 Louise stands upright again. Takes a breath, a little unnerved. And continues on to the cluster of tents, alone One soldier has remained behind as escort. Watching her w a growing suspicion. Private Lasky. With his rifle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louise sits alone, rubbing her temples. Her plate: untouc Ian enters, looking worse for wear. He grabs a pre-made m and joins Louise at her table. His eyes are bloodshot.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Didn’t expect to see you out.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: I’m hiding from Weber.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: How goes the riddle?  Tan grabs Yellow (06/11/2015) 68.

dialogues.speaker: TAN
dialogues.text: It’s a timeline. I don’t know what they’re asking me to solve. Is it about population dynamics?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Why do you go there? a salt shaker from the end of the table.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Let me tell you a story about probability. He pours a dollop of salt on the table between them. A fe quick shakes.

dialogues.speaker: IAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The current world population is hovering close to eight billion, but we started out as just a trickle, right? Things got really populated in the last couple of centuries, so here’s humanity: He then shakes out a salt line for a bit until he unscrew the cap and dumps a heap at the end. TAN (CONT’D) This line represents the population of the whole history of humanity. Estimated at just over 100 billion. What that means is: About eight percent of every human who ever lived is alive right now. And that puts us at this pileup at the end.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: The end?

dialogues.speaker: TAN
dialogues.text: Well, some people call this an “extinction burst.” I don’t, because I think it’s junk science.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: How can you be so sure?

dialogues.speaker: TAN
dialogues.text: People have been predicting the end of civilization for ages. But someone always comes along and kicks us further down the timeline.  Yellow (06/11/2015) 68A. Ian spreads out the salt like sand, and runs his finger through it in a line, punctuating one end. The timeline.  Yellow (06/11/2015) 69.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Maybe it doesn’t happen this time. They’re warning us. We’re running out of time.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: I can’t tell that to Weber.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Weber? The CIA guy is who worries me. Halpern. Louise suddenly winces and rubs her temples.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: How are you holding up?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Headaches. (beat) My brain is scrambled.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: I hear they have the prefabs up finally. We get private housing.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: (distant) Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Hey. He reaches across the table and takes her hand in his. Louise looks at Ian. Then at their hands.

dialogues.speaker: IAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We'll get through. It’s all right. She pulls her hands from him, suddenly shy.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I just... I’m feeling raw and unstable and... Colonel Weber enters the mess tent and sets his sights on Ian. Calls out from the door:

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Tan. You're needed in operations. Ian keeps his focus on Louise.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: I’1ll see you later. (once more) We’ll get a win soon. Tan leaves. When he’s gone, Louise’s headache returns.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED AT6
dialogues.text: INT. PEDIATRICIAN’S OFFICE - DAY (FLASHBACK) B76 Hannah and Louise hold hands on the exam bed. Louise is fighting back tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louise stares at a shelf full of Hannah’s awards. Photos Hannah in sports, at band concerts, in a theme park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louise is bent over in her bathroom, ill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louise is bent over a trash can as if she just vomited. S coughs, looks around like she’s lost. She notices tears in her eyes. Wipes them. It disturbs her. She fights back the intense emotional im of these memories. It takes a few breaths for her to compose herself.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (pre-lap) And why do you want to see the ships destroyed?

dialogues.speaker: TV COVERAGE
dialogues.text: Handheld camera interviewing a MIDDLE-AGED WOMAN holding sign in a protest line outside a barricade. She’s been crying; her eyes are red with tears. And she speaks Engli  78 79 80 71. Ticker at bottom of screen: “UFO ‘TRUTHER’ MOVEMENT GROWS

dialogues.speaker: MIDDLE-AGED WOMAN
dialogues.text: Because! It’s not right. We are the only ones in this universe. This whole thing is a hoax. Why d’you think they haven’t shown an alien up close? It’s all a conspiracy! The sound of a KNOCKING wrenches from the news clip to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louise wakes suddenly in bed. She’s fallen asleep atop th covers, still in her clothes. Clutching a pillow as if it were a child. The loud KNOCKING comes again. And she gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louise opens the door to find Weber and Ian standing outs their breath pluming in the cold air.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: May we come in? Louise frowns. INT. HOUSING PRE-FAB —- LIVING AREA - MOMENTS LATER 80 Louise, Weber, and Ian sit in this hotel-room-sized space

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: How are you feeling? Louise tries to read the situation. Something is wrong. Ian looks concerned. Weber looks suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: I just need sleep. I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: You want to tell me what’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: I don’t-- what, what happened?  Yellow (06/11/2015) 72.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: You used seven words in the last session you never used before. And you wrote all of them in heptapod.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: What? What words?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: You had three different exchanges no one on our side of the glass could follow.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Show me. I’1l tell you what I wrote.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: That’s not the problem here! Weber's getting more frustrated. Ian steps in to defuse:

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: All this focus on alien language. Look, I did some research and there's this idea that immersing yourself in a foreign language can rewire your brain--

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: The Sapir-Whorf hypothesis, yes. The theory that the language you speak determines how you think.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Are you dreaming in this language? Louise looks from Ian to Weber. Guarded.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: What does that...? I’ve had a few dreams. That doesn’t make me unfit for the job. Weber shows her a paper document signed at the bottom.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: This might.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: That’s just a prescription for my headaches, Kettler-- Then she notices something.  Blue Draft (05/06/2015) 73. THE SIGNATURE FORM, revealing Louise has signed her name circle. Like a cursive logogram.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Kettler tells me you signed it with your left hand. You’re right handed.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Well. I. I mean...

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: It was one thing when no one could understand them. It’s another when no one but you can. (directed at Ian) You think you can manage in the room on your own now?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: What? Louise focuses on Ian now, her eyes pleading. Ian sees her, this woman on verge of a breakdown, suddenl quite fragile. It pains him, but he believes it--

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: If I had to. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Tan. Come on. Wait, just--

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: (stands) I’m pulling you out. Louise and Ian follow. Louise intercepts Weber at the doo

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: I need to be in there. This is all I do. Take it away and I’m just a, what, a prisoner.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Louise, you just need to recover--

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: (snaps at Ian) Shut up! (to Weber) This won’t work without me. I’m the only one they really talk to.  82 83 84 Pink (05/18/2015) 74,

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Which is why I can’t afford to lose you! Do you get it now? Suddenly frustrated by his confession, Weber steps back o into the cold. But Ian pauses outside her door. Turns aro to face Louise again. Louise looks devastated; untethered.

dialogues.speaker: TAN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I got worried-- But she shuts the door on him. EXT. MONTANA LANDING SITE — MORNING 81 The Shell gleams in the rising sun, casting a shadow over slice of the science camp site the shape of a tombstone. EXT. “THE SHELL” ~ MORNING 82 Privates Lasky and Combs set heavy A/V boxes at a staging area by the scissor lift. INT. SCIENCE TENT - IAN’S AREA — MORNING 83 VIDEO of Abbott and Costello plays on a screen. The last session in the room. Fast-forwarding to the appearance of timeline. Pause. Ian studies it on the monitor at his desk. His team of SCIENCE EXPERTS argue and gesture at one another in the background, around a large table. Behind him: A glass screen displays the timeline riddle, big as life. Ian rubs his face. Downs his coffee. Goes at it again. EXT. HOUSING PRE-FAB —- MORNING 84 Weber knocks on Louise’s door. Beat. Louise opens the door just a few inches. Her eyes are bloodshot. She’s wearing yesterday’s clothes

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Did you sleep?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: A little.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: I need your brain.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: You're putting me back in?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: (evading) Do you know Mandarin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two push through the tent flap, and Louise is startle EVERY SINGLE TV SCREEN is filled with footage of violence Gunfire at the grounds of another alien site. Riots at another. Naval maneuvers on the Indian Ocean. Weber hands Louise a set of headphones, and replays a vid ON SCREEN: Spy footage of two CHINESE MEN meeting at a ca not unlike the Montana site. Muddled voices in Mandarin. Louise translates:

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: He’s saying each of the twelve is offering advanced technology. (beat) Spies report India and Sudan have already received theirs. Like sets. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sets? I don’t know what he means-—- (beat) Something about an advantage. With suits, honor, and flowers? The clip ends abruptly. Weber takes the headphones back.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: We don’t know what it means, either. But an hour ago China scrambled fighters at airfields in four different bases, and Sudan is following suit. “Big Domino” is about to start something.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Following suit... (realizing) Suits, honor, and flowers. Colonel, those are tile sets in Mahjong. Oh god, have they been using a game to converse with their heptapods?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Maybe. Probably easier than trying to teach Mandarin. Why?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Say I taught them chess instead of English. Every conversation is a game, every idea expressed through opposition-- victory and defeat. You see the problem? If all I ever give you is a hammer... Weber looks back at the monitors, suddenly getting it.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: ..-Everything’s a nail. Halpern enters, riled up. Steps up to Weber.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: May I have a word, Colonel? Weber nods to Louise: Dismissed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louise enters, distraught. Goes to her desk. ANGLE ON IAN, engrossed in his study of previous sessions until he hears Louise gathering papers at her desk.  Blue Draft (05/06/2015) 77. He sees her through the timeline screen bisecting their workspace. It’s like the glass barrier in the chamber. After a beat, he decides to approach her.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: How are you doing? She keeps gathering printouts of logograms. Shoving mater into folders.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Why do you want to know?

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Why? Because I-- because you were starting to scare me. (steps closer) You would have done the same for me, if you were in my shoes. Louise turns to him now. Vulnerable, and mad about it. Bu refusing to cry in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Oh, so I should see things from your perspective, but did you ever see it from mine? Just once? (re: Timeline) You got the symbol for ‘humanity’ wrong. Doesn’t that say it all. She walks around to the other side of the screen and make adjustments by touch. Ian watches from Louise’s desk on the other side... and h nearly gasps in surprise. From his POV, the timeline is reversed. And the logogram means ‘humanity’ now looks the same from either side.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Louise...their word is an ambigram. It reads the same front or back.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: It is? Oh-- You’re right. He marvels at this mirror image of the timeline problem.  87 Blue Draft (05/06/2015)

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: On your side, the human race is at the end of its time. But here-- to the heptapods—- we’re just getting started. The low BASS TONE reverberates through the tents.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN MARKS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ten minutes to session. Ian-- you’re up. Louise leans in to Ian to keep him focused on the problem front of him.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: How does that help us? Ian frowns, thinking... then, in a sudden Eureka moment, gets it. Claps his hands--

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: My god. It’s not a problem at all, it’s a choice. He charges off, right out of the tent.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Ian? Ian, wait—- EXT. BASE CAMP — CONTINUOUS 87 Louise trails after Ian, who’s headed right for the picku

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: What choice?

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: That’s what they’re saying. It’s like a warning label on a power tool. Whatever they’re offering us, we can use it to flourish for millions of years, or we can do something stupid and end it all right now. Halpern steps out of the Ops Tent with Weber and zeroes i Tan leading Louise for the Shell door.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: Doctor Banks! Tan grabs Louise by the hand. He’s not going in alone.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Come on. Louise hurries after Ian.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: No one authorized you back inside-- But the two pile into a pickup and Ian peels out. Halpern moves for the second truck, where two HAZMAT-suit TECHS arrive looking confused -- the rest of Ian’s team. EXT. “THE SHELL” — DAY A87 Ian slides the pickup to a stop close to the scissor lift Louise hurries out on one side, Ian following. Neither of them in suits or with respirators. In the distance, the other truck is on approach, leaving rooster tail of dust behind it. Ahead, the scissor lift DESCENDS from its high perch at t surface, revealing Lasky and Combs in full suits. Ian and Louise climb in as they step out. Louise makes ey contact with Lasky.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE LASKY
dialogues.text: You can’t go in there.

dialogues.speaker: TAN
dialogues.text: She’s with me. Ian punches the ‘up’ button on the lift. Louise checks to see how close the other truck is, but th her attention drifts back to Lasky and Combs, below. They both just stand and watch them, clutching their rifl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louise and Ian arrive to find Abbott already here, advanc for the glass barrier. Abbott’s movement suggests an urge

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Abbott?  Pink (05/18/2015) T9A. The timeline draws itself on the glass. And beneath it a symbol appears. Louise points to it: LOUISE (CONT’D) “Solve.” It’s all on you now.

dialogues.speaker: TAN
dialogues.text: Is there a symbol for “choice?” Both timelines are possible, it all depends upon what we choose to do with their offer. Louise nods. But then the tablet powers down; shorts out on its own.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Wait, what just-- Abbott writes on the barrier. Adding to the previous: LOUISE (CONT’D) “Solve here.” He wants me to write on the glass.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Can you?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: It’s a complicated sentence. I’m trying to figure it out. Louise approaches the boundary, opposite Abbott. The wall becomes more and more transparent, revealing Abb more intimately than ever before. The alien gestures at her. Louise tentatively puts up two hands, then lowers one.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: I can’t. I can’t draw both ends at the same time. She holds her right hand up against the glass. It reacts forming ink on Abbott’s side. As she does, Abbott holds up one hand against the glass o his end, to the left of her position.

dialogues.speaker: A89
dialogues.text: Yellow (06/11/2015) 79B. Louise regards him curiously. Then she takes a breath, an begins to draw one end of this elegant, complicated circl As she does, Abbott draws on his end. Working in the oppo arc toward Louise’s starting point.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: What is he doing? Louise’s eyes widen as she realizes...

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: He's being my other arm. He’s finishing my sentence. The two co-authors finish simultaneously, connecting the of their logograms into a circle. REVEAL an angle showing Abbott's hand perfectly aligned w Louise’s, only the transparent wall between them.

dialogues.speaker: QUICK POP
dialogues.text: INT. LAKE HOUSE - HANNAH’S ROOM - DAY (FLASHBACK) BA89 Baby Hannah reaches up from her cradle, her little infant hand outstretched like Abbott’s. Louise reaching down to Hannah grip mom’s pointer finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louise snaps out of that quick vision. She takes a step b

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: That’s... That’s it. Looking at it head-on, the logogram is complete. Then: A tapestry of heptapod logograms begin flowing acro the entire transparent wall, like wallpaper patterns. They appear with dozens of GEOMETRIC EQUATIONS. Circles. Angular shapes. Equations in heptapod with Arabic numeral around them like liner notes. A waterfall of data. It pou down the screen. PRESSING IN on Ian, who smiles broadly.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: This is it. (into headset) This is the gift!  Yellow (06/11/2015) 79C.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (over headset) We got it over here. (to Tech) Christ, how much is this -- (back to Ian) It’s two terabytes of data.  Yellow (06/11/2015) 80. Abbott begins miming the “walk” action they taught earlie Simultaneously, a new set of logograms form from ink splattered harshly against the glass --

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: What is he saying? Louise approaches the barrier, frowning. Meanwhile, a faint BEEPING begins quickening somewhere in interview chamber.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Those are our names... (translating) Must leave? (to Abbott) You're asking us to go? She gets close now-- Ian approaches a DUFFEL BAG toppled by the glass barrier the floor, getting closer to the sound-~ Pulling it away to reveal: A_set of wired C4 CHARGES stuc against the glass--

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Louise! Ian runs to grab Louise-- Louise looks back at Abbott-- he’s warning them-- Suddenly the gravity shifts in the chamber-- Louise and I find themselves sliding AWAY from the barrier, right back into the tunnel-- Louise looks one last time at Abbott and sees: He’s pressing his seven-fingered hand to the glass once m The way he did when she first shared her name. This image shrinks as gravity takes Louise away from the chamber and then with a cacophonous BOOM-- The interview chamber is ENGULFED IN A FIREBALL, with an impact so hard Louise sees it SHATTER THE BARRIER-- Ian and Louise stop sliding, but then the firecloud rolls toward them out the chamber and into the tunnel--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 90 Pink (05/18/2015) 81-82. BLACK. NO SOUND. A beat. Then: INT. LAKE HOUSE - HANNAH’S ROOM - MORNING (FLASHBACK) B89 Louise and 4-year-old Hannah are on the bed. Louise has fallen asleep with a storybook on her lap. Hannah leans i and WHISPERS into Louise’s ear-- Louise’s eyes SNAP OPEN--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT on Louise waking with a start. A bandage has been taped to her forehead. She sits up, and instantly regrets it. Her head hurts. Kettler approaches.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KETTLER
dialogues.text: Careful. You suffered a concussion.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Tan... Is he--

dialogues.speaker: DR. KETTLER
dialogues.text: Three broken ribs and a sprained ankle, but otherwise he’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: How long was I out?

dialogues.speaker: DR. KETTLER
dialogues.text: About two hours. Been strangely quiet ever since. Kettler tends to her, examines her pulse and temperature.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Who...?

dialogues.speaker: DR. KETTLER
dialogues.text: It was a couple of soldiers. They’d been watching too much TV, afraid the gift was going to kill us all.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: We don’t need help from another race to do that. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (then) What happened to them? The soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KETTLER
dialogues.text: The agency man, Halpern, he shot them, but it was too late. Outside: The entire camp is mobilized. One tent one the e of camp is in the process of being collapsed. Even more sobering: A truck parks nearby, towing the SCIS LIFT used to get up into the Shell.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: What’s going on now?

dialogues.speaker: DR. KETTLER
dialogues.text: Preparing to evacuate. Louise tenses. She looks around -- Ian isn’t in the tent.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Where is Ian?

dialogues.speaker: DR. KETTLER
dialogues.text: Weber came and got him, maybe ten minutes ago. He wouldn’t leave until he knew you were okay. But your whole tent is on the clock to figure out whatever it is you were given up there. Because we’re pulling up stakes. Louise immediately gets up, past Kettler, and goes for th tent exit. DR. KETTLER (CONT’D) Medevac is on the way!  91

dialogues.text: Pink (05/18/2015) 85. 92 93  Pink (05/18/2015) 86-88.  94 Pink (05/18/2015) 89. INT. SCIENCE TENT - CRYPTO ROOM —- THAT MOMENT 94 The alien data spreads across all the flatscreens. Weber watches it, arms crossed. Ian stands at one computer, cycling through some subset o the data. His button-down shirt is loose, showing the tig bandage wrap around his ribs underneath.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Is this all of it? The feed wasn’t cut before the explosion?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Not as far as we can tell. Ian is visibly relieved.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: We should combine my team with Louise’s and get them all working on this.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: I don’t know yet. But they’re finally speaking my language. Louise enters the tent, shoving the flap aside. Weber sees her coming.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Doctor Banks--

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: We are not leaving.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Glad to see you’re awake.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: (rolling through it) We need to get back in there, talk to them, explain what happened, it wasn’t our fault——

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: You’re not going back inside.  95 Pink (05/18/2015) 89A.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: We have to.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: What happened in there was an attack. We can hope for the best, but I have orders to prepare for a retaliation. So we’re leaving in twenty-four hours.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: That’s the wrong move. As long as they stay, we have to stay. We have to keep talking. A low, STRANGE TONE reverberates through the tent. This one is not the tone they’ve heard before. And it’s accompanied by a RUMBLE. EXT. SCIENCE TENT — DAY 95 Louise, Ian and Weber emerge from the tent to see:  96 97 Yellow (06/11/2015) 90. The Shell lifts higher into the sky. It rises, vibrating everyone’s rib cages, the air beneath undulating as if reflected on water. Then, several hundred feet up... it stops. And hovers. Parked there. Staring down.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Well. They’re not leaving.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Why does this feel worse. EXT. SCIENCE TENT — NIGHT 96 Outside, the canopy of stars above is staggering. The Shell remains in the sky, partially eclipsing the moo Tilting down to find the Ops Tent, bustling with activity

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close in: the data playing out on a large flatscreen. The twelve landing site MONITORS are all black. Ian and Louise sit together, down from their early high o receiving the gift. Now they face a mountain of material.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: I don’t get it.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: We’ve only been at this an hour.

dialogues.speaker: TAN
dialogues.text: No, I mean-~ what is it?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: I recognize maybe one in every twenty logograms. It will take some time to unpack the rest.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: But look at their math. This is their code; their building blocks. But I don’t know where anything starts or ends! It may as well be random. Strange RORSCHARCH-LIKE DIAGRAMS animate on screen.  98 Blue Draft (05/06/2015) 91.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: It can’t be random.

dialogues.speaker: TAN
dialogues.text: I know. Tan gets up and starts pacing. Stares at the dark monitor

dialogues.speaker: TAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I wonder how the Brits are doing. He kicks at the back of his chair and storms off. Louise is too tired to get up and go after him. Her eyes heavy and she’s still wounded from the explosion. She rak her fingers through her long hair and stares at the scree

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What’s this term here? INT. LAKE HOUSE - LOUISE’S STUDY - NIGHT (FLASHBACK) 98 Louise reads papers at her desk. She runs her fingers thr her short hair, like she just did. Her study is walled with books, and her desk allows her a view through the open door all the way down the hall. Hannah (age 12) steps to the threshold. Leans against it.

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: Mom.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Sweetie.

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: What's the term for that thing, like a technical term, where we make like a deal, and we both get something out of it?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: A compromise?

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: You remember what it sounds like?  Blue Draft (05/06/2015) 92.

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: Like it’s a competition but both sides end up happy.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Like a win-win?

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: More science-y than that.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: You want science, call your father. Louise returns to her papers. Hannah frowns.

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: You always do that. You and Dad. Put in just a little effort and then kick me to the other parent.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Hannah, that’s not fair.

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: It really isn’t! She storms off down the hall. Louise watches her go. Trie think of what to say.

dialogues.speaker: TAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Louise-- 99 INT. SCIENCE TENT —- LOUISE’S DESK - DAY 99 Louise snaps her head up, having drifted off to sleep at work table surrounded by computers.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: No. I’m up. (then) What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: That question is irrelevant, if you’re a heptapod. He smiles at her. Eager.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: You cracked something. Didn’t you.  Yellow (06/11/2015) 93. Ian nods. He grabs a bottle of HAND SANITIZER stowed atop comms shelf and his pen-sized laser pointer.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: I found something that demonstrated Fermat's Principle of Least Time. Tan shines the laser at the sanitizer and oddly, we can S THE BEAM cutting through the bottle. Ian moves the pointe he talks, demonstrating: IAN (CONT’D) (beat) Light always knows the shortest route to a point in terms of time, even if it has to change course. For a long time we thought it was cheating. Like how does it know the shortest path is this curve?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: The heptapods know?

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: More than that. He triggers an animation sequence of data that looks like three-dimensional network of nodes. Then one strand GLOWS inside the network, linking two disparate parts. IAN (CONT’D) It’s how they see everything. How they travel. Except the shortest path is outside space and time. With this, we could build a space ship with no rockets. We’d just-- (snaps fingers) ~-and we're there. Louise catches her breath.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: It's not a weapon.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Well... Nobel thought the same of dynamite... Nonetheless, Louise is visibly relieved. IAN (CONT’D) There’s something else. At the tail end of the code.  Yellow (06/11/2015) 93A. Tan makes a few keystrokes on a monitor and brings up an image on a large flat-screen.  100 Pink (05/18/2015) 94, THE SCREEN shows a series of intertwined logograms. Like Persian rug of alien data. Ian magnifies one corner... revealing: “1 / 12" -- followed by an elegant little symbol. TAN (CONT’D) They used Arabic numerals. “One of twelve.”

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: (a-ha moment) Do you know what this means? INT. OPERATIONS TENT - “WAR ROOM” — DAY 100 Connected to the Operations tent, but made private, walle off from the screens and the noise. Mainly it’s just a conference table, some comms gear, and a world map. Louise, flanked by Ian, confronts Colonel Weber at the conference table with Agent Halpern. She holds up the printout.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: This is just one piece of it. What they're telling us, right here, is that ours is one of twelve. We’re part of a larger whole.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: Or we’re one of twelve contestants for the prize.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: (to Weber) Why do I have to talk to him?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: You did your job, now he gets to run the show.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: (to Halpern) We need to talk to the other sites and help them with whatever they've gotten from the other heptapods.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: In case you don’t remember, we're blacked out. So are the other nations. We’re on our own.  Pink (05/18/2015) 95.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: This is telling us the pieces go together.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: And I’m telling you no one else believes that. Halpern swivels his laptop around and shows a recording: AGENT HALPERN (CONT’D) Two hours ago we pulled this audio off a secure channel in Russia. Someone on the science team there was broadcasting wide. He clicks playback, and we see a screen go black with Eng translation appearing as the recording plays over the sou of pounding on the door--

dialogues.speaker: RUSSIAN SCIENTIST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Their final words translate to, “There is no time, many become one.” I fear we have all been given weapons because we answered the timeline wrong, please, if you-- With the CRACK of a gunshot the recording abruptly ends. Louise begins to fray at the edges. Staving off panic:

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Well, I mean, there are ways to interpret what he said...

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: I don’t need an interpreter to know what this means. Russia just executed one of their own experts to keep their secrets. He clicks through to show on his monitor: Every Shell now hovers over their site. From Hokkaido to Wales, the massive spheres hang in the air. Waiting.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: “Many become one” could just be their way of saying “some assembly required...”  101 Blue Draft (05/06/2015) 96.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: Why hand it out to us in pieces? Why not just give it all over?

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: What better way to force us all to work together, for once? Halpern looks to the other people in the room. Weber stud him carefully. Ian nods, in support of Louise.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: Even if I did believe you, how in the world are you going to get anyone else to play along and give up their data? Ian jumps on this one:

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: We offer our own in return. Halpern looks to Weber. Is he serious?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: A trade.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: So it’s a non-zero-sum game. Louise hears this and it dawns on her-- INT. LAKE HOUSE - LOUISE’S STUDY - NIGHT (FLASHBACK) 101 Hannah storms down the hall. Picking up right where we le her from the previous flashback. Louise sits forward, with that same look of realization:

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: A non-zero-sum game! Hannah stops. Turns back around.

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: That’s it! Yes! Thank you, Mom. Hannah shuffles back into her room. Louise slowly touches her face, an even deeper question n creeping into her mind: Did I just alter my own past?  102 Pink (05/18/2015) 97.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (pre-lap) What did you just do? Louise seems to hear the voice beside her and look-- INT. OPERATIONS TENT - “WAR ROOM” - BACK TO SCENE 102 Weber stands at her side. Behind him, by a set of comms stations, Halpern and his team are on phones.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: I’m-- I’m sorry?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Nobody locks horns with the CIA like that. What motivated you? Louise is still a bit lost, reeling from the effect she j had on her own memory.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Family. Weber is surprised and confused by this answer. They’re interrupted by Halpern, who steps up with:

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: Nine of the landing sites have gone total comms blackout. Only way to reach them is to physically drive there and yell at the border guard. Which we're doing, but it won’t be fast enough.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: There's gotta be some way to get a message to them.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: To our allies, maybe, but at this stage it’s too little too late. What we need is to get all the nations online before one starts global war, and there’s no way for us to reach them. It’s a living nightmare for Louise; all that needs to hap is for people to talk to each other, but no one will. The

dialogues.speaker: IAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes there is.

dialogues.speaker: B102
dialogues.text: Blue Draft (05/06/2015) 98. All eyes on Ian.

dialogues.speaker: IAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s right over our heads. He taps a screen displaying the Shell hovering outside.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: Maybe you see how that’s problematic for us now. PRESSING ON LOUISE, as the others discuss options:

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And if their intent is global war?

dialogues.speaker: IAN, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: Then at least we know.

dialogues.speaker: QUICK POP
dialogues.text: INT. CYLINDER CHAMBER — DAY A102 Louise is in a dark space of unknown dimension, lit from bright light on one side, wearing a breathing mask, her h dancing weightlessly around her face-- INT. OPERATIONS TENT - “WAR ROOM” — BACK TO SCENE B102 She snaps out of the vision, looks around: The men are still arguing.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: I’m not having our decisions outsourced to the enemy--

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: They aren’t the enemy, when have they made any act of aggression toward us?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: Maybe this is their way of being aggressive!

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: That isn’t the question.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Then what is?  103 104 Al04 B1l04 Pink (05/18/2015) 99.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL WEBER
dialogues.text: How do we get you back in the room when it’s half a mile straight up?

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: I’m sure Louise would-- They all look to where Louise was standing. She’s gone now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s raining when Ian, Halpern, and Weber step out. Halpe is first to point out:

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN
dialogues.text: Vehicle's missing. Another low BASS TONE emanates from the ship-- and it see to PUSH THE CLOUDS around it like a ripple on water. INT. “THE SHELL” - CONTINUOUS Alo4 FROM BLACK, a circle of BLACK separates and shrinks. It takes us a moment to realize we’re inside the ship, looking straight down as a cylinder descends to the groun

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ian grabs a pair of binoculars from an OFFICER and looks in the direction of where the Shell had been.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through magnification he sees the cylinder descend... And where it lands is close to where LOUISE now waits for Both of them are tiny, almost silhouettes at this range. But it looks like Louise has a breathing mask in her hand

dialogues.speaker: AGENT HALPERN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What the hell is she doing? She steps into the cylinder.

dialogues.speaker: TAN
dialogues.text: What you hired her to do.  106 107 108 Yellow (06/11/2015) 100. INT. CYLINDER CHAMBER — CONTINUOUS 105 Plain, dimly-lit from below, cramped. Louise puts her fingers on the inside wall, feeling it-- --and then the cylinder seals her up inside, in darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cylinder elevator lifts off. Noiselessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louise can feel the acceleration in her stomach, and in t pitch of the low tone reverberating inside. She looks around for anything else in the chamber with he No windows. No views outside. Outside the walls of the chamber, another metallic ROAR. Followed by a distant HIGH PITCH. Louise waits for a portal to open. None do. She’s trapped inside this space.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: «.-Hello? At her feet, light sets the floor aglow. And then a luminous GAS seeps in and begins to rise aroun her. Filling the cylinder.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh god-- oh god oh god-- Louise puts on the oxygen mask as the barrier rises up to shoulders, then her neck and finally up over her head-- UNDERNEATH, the world is bright and mostly clear, and yet Louise’s hair drifts up around her face as if she were underwater. Louise breathes through the mask. Looks aroun A portal opens up opposite her. Light shines on her face. INT. “THE SHELL” - CONTINUOUS 108 Louise steps out to a dimensionless sea of bright mist.  Yellow (06/11/2015) 101. No walls or ceiling. She looks up to see what might be a heptapod drifting int the white void far above her. Her breath is shallow. She is in a truly alien place now. There is no reference for this experience. Something dark and enormous “swims” through the mist, pas by her, always just far enough to make it impossible to s clearly -- it could be a swarm of small things, or someth the size of a blue whale. And then a heptapod approaches from behind her. Louise sp around in time to see it as its seven limbs advance to he Beat. She finally controls her breathing.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: Costello? Costello stands with limbs poised before her... Then the mist clears a bit, revealing more of his heptapo body. The limbs and torso? What seemed to be the entire f of the alien? Not so. It is more like the fingers and han a much larger being. Costello towers over her. She looks up, in awe. And then it writes on the invisible floor beneath them. W two fingers. Ink sluicing out from them into a logogram. SUBTITLES: “Louise.” Louise takes a breath. LOUISE (CONT’D) Where is Abbott? Costello moves the ink around with one appendage and a ne logogram forms. SUBTITLES: “Abbott is dead.” Louise holds her stomach, she’s hit so hard by this. LOUISE (CONT’D) I’m sorry. We are sorry. The logogram ink shifts again. Louise looks down to read SUBTITLES: “Abbott chooses to save Louise and Ian.”  Yellow (06/11/2015) 101A. Another ink-shift for a second logogram: SUBTITLES: “Louise has question?” Louise remembers her mission. Her reason for making the t LOUISE (CONT’D) I need... need you to send a message. To the other sites. Costello replies by modifying the first logogram. SUBTITLES: “Message here. Louise has weapon.” LOUISE (CONT’D) That’s just it, I-- (directly) What is your purpose here?
